reviews.content: Written by John Landis and Dan Aykroyd and starring a whopping cast of acting and musical stars, this 1980 film is musical, comedy, adventure, with a bit of fantasy thrown in too. The characters Jake and Elwood Blues were created by Belushi and Aykroyd as a sketch on "Saturday Night Live", with additional input from Howard Shore. Considering the way, the concept was birthed, this film became a success both commercially and as a cult film, pathing the way for the fictional brothers to be featured in other mediums too, including the music charts and video games - not to mention a sequel 1998 too.After serving 3 years in prison, Jake Blues is picked up by his brother Elwood, in the Bluesmobile - an old police car. They pay a visit to Sister Mary Stigmata that the Roman Catholic orphanage they grew up in will be closed unless $5,000 in property taxes is paid. Initially they are reluctant to help, but during a sermon by Reverend Cleophus James at the Triple Rock Baptist church Jake has an epiphany and decides to re-form the Blues Brothers band and help. The police are immediate on their tail as Elwood is driving with a suspended license and has over 100 unpaid parking tickets as well as over 50 moving violations. Not only are the police on their tale, but a mysterious woman seems intent on ending their lives with an arsenal of weapons. After escaping the police and near death, the Blues Brothers embark on a mission to pull the band back together. The band have all being doing other jobs while Jake was in prison, and some of them are harder to persuade than others. Once the band are back together, the next obstacle to overcome it getting gigs, but the Blues Brothers are crafty, and have some old friends they can try to persuade too. After putting on a big show at the Palace Hotel Ballroom, north of Chicago, they then have to race to the Chicago City Hall building to pay off the debt they have been on a mission on to clear. As well as the police and an angry woman, they also have trouble with other people they have upset along the way, including a country and western band, and a branch of the Illinois Nazis.Filmed all over Chicago and acting as an advertisement for the film industry to consider Chicago for future films, the spectacle that audiences eventually got, if you discount the different cut releases, was a fun and entertaining thrill ride which brought adventure and great music into people's lives. It also showcased the great American city, and it landscapes and features. I remember my parents bringing the VHS version of this home one day and watching in awe as cars did miraculous and ludicrous stunts. I was in awe of how to guys in black suits, hats, and sunglasses, raced across Chicago with so many pursuers and did not get stopped or killed. I fell in love with this film the very first time I watched it and have enjoyed every subsequent viewing of it since. I have a copy of the soundtrack that accompanied the film, I have other "Blues Brothers" records too, and I've been to see many a tribute act putting on their own "Blues Brothers" show. Having come from a sketch on "Saturday Night Live" this film has since transcended its humble beginning and because a cult film the likes of which have not been seen since. Sure, there is the sequel to this first film, but for me that does not come close this masterpiece. It is a musical tour-de-force that should not work but somehow does. It features some of the best car chases in history, foot-tapping and sing along musical numbers, raw and dark humour mixed with some fun visual slapstick, and lots and lots of entertainment. This film knows it is over the top, and revels in it - you just have to watch the Bluesmobile doing a twisting backflip as it reverses off a broken highway bridge to avoid the Illinois Nazis. Aykroyd and Belushi make a great double act bouncing off each other and leading this film, and with Landis telling a straightforward story that does not alienate audiences, with lots of pace and excitement, this is indeed a wonderful film.

Two musicians are on a mission to make enough money to save an orphanage from closing.This is a classic musical comedy with fantastic humour, great music, and highly entertaining spectacle.I have to admit, as an 80s child, to being not only a fanboy of this movie, but for always having a great deal of man-love for Dan Ackroyd as a writer and performer.The plot is incredibly simple and functions as a means of getting from one gag or musical number to the next. It is very much character driven, with Jake and Elwood, for me, being one of the most inspired and entertaining double acts to come out of Saturday Night Live. The concept of them being so openly criminal, yet doing it all for a wonderfully good cause makes them the very definition of lovable rogues.There are so many hilarious sight gags and moments of funny banter, it is hard to pick out favourites. I love the scene in Bob's Country Bunker, likewise the destruction of the shopping mall, the Palace Hotel Ballroom show, and the final big chase.There are a number of great support performances such as Carrie Fisher, John Candy, Charles Napier, and Henry Gibson. Plus musical legends James Brown, Aretha Franklin, Ray Charles, John Lee Hooker, Cab Calloway and Chaka Khan all perform.If you like the culture of soul revivalist music and the city of Chicago this is a fantastic tribute to it all.The cinematography set around various Chicago locations is excellent and works so well for the story, music and humour. The city is almost an extra character in the movie.Both Ackroyd and James Belushi are brilliant in most scenes. Belushi makes me laugh without even saying anything.I am probably rating it higher than it really deserves out of the bias associated with a long time admiration for the movie, stars, humour, and music, but I don't care. It recently held my 6 year old daughter's attention for the duration (I skipped past the f-bombs) which is another plus point in my book.

I missed "The Blues Brothers" when it was in the theater. I saw it the first time it aired on network tv. That first time it left me a little flat. I don't know why. Over these many years I have grown to see "The Blues Brothers" for what it is. It's one of the greatest movies ever made. It's a wildly entertaining experience. It never gets old. The music is terrific. The movie looks great and the cast is even better. There may be a joke that doesn't work here or there but who care? If a batter misses a couple of pitches before he hits a home run, what's the difference? "The Blues Brothers" is one of the Top 20 Movies of All-Time.

reviews.review_title: Brilliant Musical Comedy...When Landis Isn't Trying To Destroy Chicago, That Is
reviews.content: What do you get when you get two of the most famous alums from "Saturday Night Live", who concoct two blues musicians into their own musical act. Well, when we are talking about Dan Aykroyd and John Belushi, you get The Blues Brothers. Their pairing was one of the great highlights of SNL's first several years on NBC, leading to a hit album. And then it led into a wildly successful, but also arguably wildly overblown, 1980 smash hit film.Aykroyd and Belushi are, respectively, Ellwood and Jake Blues, a pair of Chicago-based blues musicians. Belushi is the one gets released from jail; and when the two of them get back together, they find out that the orphanage where they were raised is about to get shut down by the Windy City Archdiocese; and the only way they figure that the place can be preserved is to raise the $5,000 property tax owed by the Cook County assessor's office, and do it in an eleven-day span. They get a lot of help from some very famous people (Ray Charles, James Brown, Aretha Franklin, Cab Calloway, and dozens of others) in what Aykroyd always refers to as their "mission from God", but they also attract some exceptionally unwanted attention from a lot of crazy people, including a neo-Nazi nutcase (Henry Gibson), a deranged woman (Carrie Fisher), and what seems to be the whole Illinois law enforcement community. The result is a lot of fun in the various musical sequences, especially given the people involved.That said, however, in the final half hour, as Aykroyd and Belushi make their 106-mile run into Chicago (with, of course, a full tank of gas, half a pack of cigarettes, in the middle of the night, and with both of them wearing sunglasses), THE BLUES BROTHERS becomes a wild destruction derby, in which the Windy City is for all intents and purposes trashed to hell and back, that is as ear-splitting (if not more so) as it is funny. Even by 21st century standards, this mayhem, concocted by director John Landis under the rather skewed idea that bigger is always better, especially as he had a (then) extravagant $30 million budget to fool around with, and still decades away from the CGI of, say, AVENGERS: ENDGAME, is still as overcooked as hell. Pile-ups of cop cars (seemingly hundreds), combined with explosions, the over-the-top death of Gibson (his Nazi car falls off a bridge 1,400 feet downward, like Slim Pickens riding the Bomb in DOCTOR STRANGELOVE), and the destruction of a shopping mall are only funny up to a point before they just become excuses for equating destruction with laughs; and this is something that Landis frequently misses the boat on (as did Steven Spielberg in his wildly overblown 1979 WW II comedy "1941"). However, during the final sequence of mayhem, Landis does stage quite the masterful car chase underneath Chicago's elevated train tracks that would seem to pay homage to the similar one involving Gene Hackman in the 1971 classic THE FRENCH CONNECTION.Despite what may seem to be churlish criticisms on my part, I am not going to demote this film in any way. Clearly Aykroyd and Belushi (the latter on those days when he didn't have his face in the very white powder that would cut his life prematurely short) do a great job in their roles, in those moments where Landis' "bigger is better" directing style gets out of the way, along with Spielberg himself in the brief role of the Cook County assessor's office clerk at the end, and of course all the musical greats. Thus, despite Landis' penchant for overblown action and violent destruction, THE BLUES BROTHERS does remain one hugely entertaining musical comedy, both for its time and, arguably, for all time.

Forget everything you've known about musical movies. If you haven't seen "the blues brothers" yet I guaranty you'll love it and it will knock you off your legs. The story of two brothers trying to bring their band back together to raise money and save their orphanage From shutting down is a creative and more original story than it seems and has never been done before. These blues brothers are on more than an adventure, they are on a mission from god. And that's all it needs. The whole movie is just funny, wacky, dramatic and amazing. John Belushi and Dan Aykroyd are the main stars of the show along with the band and some of the best Jazz and blues singers of all time. This movie is so much fun I've watched it at least 5 times and I'm not tired of it. Overall I definitely recommend to watch it cause it has a killing soundtrack and a magnificent plot.

reviews.review_title: As a musical, it's doing something right
reviews.content: John Landis' movie doesn't quite cut the mustard but it consistently hits the goal-posts. It looks fabulous, (it's like a Frank Tashlin movie from the fifties on a much larger scale). What it is, really, is a series of sketches, some of them terrific, rather than a plot, interrupted by some great musical numbers. It may be a terrible film, (it's like a big screen version of "Saturday Night Live"), but it has two great iconic moments.Aretha Franklin plays a waitress and gets to strut her stuff and sing "Think" and it's a legendary moment, and Cab Callaway gets to do "Minnie the Moocher" in front of a large audience and he's magnificent. And any movie that has Ray Charles and James Brown in it is doing something right. The film quickly developed a cult following and has since spawned a stage show based on it's leading characters. It has become something of a classic. It's certainly a guilty pleasure. In Italy, Fellini might have made something like this on an off-day and if he was in a good mood. Unfortunately, the climatic chase, while spectacular, does drag on a bit (and what a waste of 1000 extras).

The Blues Brothers (1980) *** (out of 4) Madhouse from John Landis has Jake and Elwood Blues (John Belushi, Dan Aykroyd) getting their band back together so that they can raise $5,000 to save their orphanage where they were raised. At first it seems like raising the cash will be easy but the brothers soon have Nazies, cops, angry cowboys and others chasing them through Chicago. THE BLUES BROTHERS is one of the most entertaining bad movies I've ever seen. There's so many great things in this movie but at the same time there are so many things that bothered me and kept me from enjoying the picture even more. We'll start with the bad and I'd say it's obvious that there's no story here. Instead of an actual story we just get non-stop music scenes as well as car crashes, two things that actually work in the movie but the extended running time is just way too long and I was constantly looking at the watch to see how much longer there was. The lack of any real story and the extended running time are certainly the two things that keep this from being better because outside of this there's quite a bit to enjoy here. The best thing is the fact that Landis pretty much throws everything out the window and right at the viewer. This includes some of the craziest, most over-the-top chase/wreck scenes that you're ever going to witness. There are many throughout the picture but for me the highlight would have to be the one inside the mall where everything in sight gets destroyed at least twice. Another good thing the film has going for it are some of the musical performances especially the ones dealing with Ray Charles, Cab Calloway, Aretha Franklin and John Lee Hooker. Then, of course, you've got Belushi and Aykroyd turning in great performances as the Blue Brothers. You can't help but feel like you're watching real brothers doing real blues. THE BLUES BROTHERS is far from perfect but there's still enough here that makes it worth viewing.

reviews.review_title: THERES 106 MILES TO CHICAGO, WE'VE GOT A FULL TANK OF GAS, HALF PACK OF CIGARETTES, ITS DARK OUT AND WE'RE WEARING SUNGLASSES!!
reviews.content: Blues Brothers was one of the iconic films of the 80s and when I first watched it I truly didnt get what the deal was, just seemed to be crazy over the top with no purpose but watching it again it had way more purpose than I gave it credit for. Elwood and Jake needed $5000 and had to get the band together to play one big show but encountered so many bumps in the road. It was funny and bombastic...John Belushi was fantastic and carried the show and random acts of violence from Carrie Fisher added to it.

reviews.review_title: I love this movie. One of the best 80s comedies
reviews.content:
John Belushi and Dan Aykroyd make up some of the best comic moments of the screen of the 80s. The Music in this movie es a key and is perfect for the plot. Big stars like Aretha Franklin and James Brown (and all Stars) give a special touch to the film.
All the cameos are great. An Carrie Fisher plays a very different role than we know her and she does it really well.A cult film that offers us action, adventure and great humor.Jake and Elwood Blues are great chararacters and this movie proves it.

Jake Blues gets out of prison a bit early thanks to good behavior. He joins his Elwood in a crappy car and they go to see Sister Mary "The Penguin" Stigmata. She gives a task of gaining 5000 dollars to save the boarding school they grew up in. The only problem? They have to do it the honest way. Can they get the money earnestly together with their blues band or do they have to take more extreme measures?The Blues Brothers defines the word "cool". Terrific music throughout, wildly chaotic car chases plus the right mix of highkey and lowkey comedy. But most of all it's the duo of Jake and Elwood which has given it the reputation it has. They are so levelheaded throughout that even when someone tries to outright blow them up, they carry on like nothing has happened. They don't let barriers push them down, they break through every barrier with a crash. Elwood is granted the more optimistic one of the two, but both of them work together very hard and find a solution to any problem no matter how hopeless it may seem. Their nice, brotherly friendship helps make this film as memorable as it is. Dan Aykroyd gives a great straightfaced performance and his deadpan delivery of the lines makes them all the funnier. I'd never seen anything with John Belushi before, but he makes a strong first impression on me. He's simply hysterical as Jake, and provides most of the comedy in the film with his character's crazy impulses such as singing passionately in an all-black church and his rendition of the Rawhide theme. I also love how convincingly he tricks his ex-wife (played by the equally brilliant Carrie Fisher) into sparing him and his brother by giving such a heartfelt speech I wondered if they suddenly were gonna patch things up, only for him to literally throw her in the mud instead.Of course though, what would a movie about blues be without the music? We have cameos from legends like Ray Charles, Cab Calloway, James Brown and Aretha Franklin, who all get a chance to shine musically as well as comedically. Franklin's musical number is both amusing and incredibly sung and Ray Charles is charming as the friendly, but slightly greedy instrument shop owner. Aykroyd and Belushi sing surprisingly well when they finally arrive at their own concert they are late to (you'll know why once you see it) with the song Everybody Needs Somebody To Love. Like every catchy tune, it got stuck in my head like a suction cup.Although it's not the funniest 80's comedy I've seen, it's one of the most entertaining ones to watch.

This movie is a landmark-it was responsible for Chicago becoming the setting for a number of future movies. On its own, it is based on a Saturday Night Live sketch about two white characters with pretensions of being blues musicians. Add a number of major real-life blues musicians and an even larger number of car crashes, and that's the recipe for the movie.The premise is about two brothers, one just out of Joliet prison, who try to raise money to save an orphanage from closing down, and to do so, bring together the members of their old band. Of course, their efforts to do so end up causing trouble with the law, as well as other people (such as a country and western-themed bar and the band that was supposed to play there). In the end, dozens of police cars chase after them, and even the National Guard, before they fulfill their quest. There are some genuinely funny parts, but overall the whole movie depends on exaggeration-twenty police cars crashing into twenty police cars, as critic Roger Ebert had put it.

This is an excellent movie, rich with comedy and music. It's about 2 corrupt brothers, who wish to help a nun. The story starts with Jake (John Belushi) being released from prison, where Elwood (Dan Aykroyd) picks him up. The story proceeds with them trying to honestly earn 5,000 dollars. They start by getting a little "churching up" and then try to put "the band" back together. With them continuing, and playing shows for meager amounts of money, finally get a break, and make a huge gig in a fancy hotel! While avoiding hundreds (literally) of cops, and "They can't catch us--we're on a mission from God". While making friends (and enemies) along the way, providing a side-busting movie! A must have for all good DVD collections!
Funny, epic, very entertaining and with good music, it is one of the best comedies in the history of cinema. TOTALLY RECOMMENDED!

An oddball film for sure by John Landis, possibly his oddest of all, and yet somehow it works. Half of this is a musical featuring some of the biggest names in American music history and the songs are well staged and highly enjoyable. The other half is a GONE IN 60 SECONDS-style car chase movie prioritising vehicular mayhem over everything else in sight. Impossible to dislike a film with such a larger-than-life cast, and even that lengthy running time just whizzes past. It might not be high art, but it's fun!

reviews.review_title: What Else Is There To Say?
reviews.content: This film is a classic in every sense, I've seen it so many times I can't believe it took me this long to write something about it. It mixes two of my favourite things; comedy and music. Plus I'm a huge Saturday Night Live fan, I've got the vinyl record that I've listened to multiple times, it features legendary musicians. Just do yourself a service and watch this film if you haven't already! Consider it your mission from god!

reviews.review_title: The only movie that will make you get up and dance
reviews.content:
This movie is just awesome. The music is phenomenal, the cast is amazing and the story is great. The music legends in this movie are also great. They aren't just a random big name extra, a lot of them play a big part in the movie. In conclusion,
I recommend this movie if you want to have a sing and a dance aswell as a laugh.
10/10

Comedies are always subjective. What is funny to some people may be offensive to others. I have always found slapstick comedies to be pointless films that literally don't require any brain power to get through. But take what I say with a grain of salt because I am usually harsh on these movies. With that being said i'm from Chicago and I adore the music in the movie so you would think I love this movie, you're wrong.There are only certain movies that can truly pull off this type of tone. Having ridiculous over-the-top action sequences is fine once in awhile, but when you have them in 50% of your movie and have the scenes go on for 10-15 minutes at a time, you have a problem. To me the film just got stupid after awhile. There wasn't a single laugh out loud moment, just a few chuckles. People have always told me that Aykroyd and Belushi were the greatest comedic duo ever on screen. While they had great chemistry, nothing they said together really made me laugh.I wanted to love this film. In fact it goes against my blood to dislike this film. I live in the Chicago suburbs and grew up listening to these songs play on the streets of Chicago so it pains me to say this film is ridiculously not funny. It was cool seeing celebrity cameos and hearing the songs being played but in all, it was a huge letdown.+Cameos +Music -I didn't really laugh -Unnecessarily long runtime-Over-the-top action sequences -Scenes would drag on for far too long5.0/10

I watched this movie over and over obsessively as a kid. I watched it tonight for the first time in over 25 years. It's still a great film. The action, the music, the dark humour. It's got everything. Ackroyd and Bellushi were a match made in heaven. The world is truly lucky that this incredible film was made and people can continue to enjoy it for generations to come.

reviews.review_title: Cats don't make good catholics: they can't kneel and feel no shame
reviews.content: Basically that is the feel of the Blues Brothers movie. Cool cats like Dan Aykroyd and James Belushi are the Blues brothers and they are on a mission (presumably from God) to get 5000$ for the catholic orphanage where they grew up. So they get "the band" back together in order to play the concert of their lives and get the money. They do it by shamelessly cheating people, stealing stuff, running away from police, being chased by Nazis, cowboys, police and finally the army.The film is filled with good old blues music, just look at the cast and you will see the many famous people in the business singing and playing. Based on a Saturday Night Live sketch, the movie wrecked 103 cars in the over the top car chase scenes and it is just concentrated fun in a can. Do watch it, do enjoy it.

reviews.review_title: Cataclysmic car crash musical comedy with two great stars , James Belushi and Dan Aykroyd
reviews.content: Stunning and engagingly noisy comedy does have its great moments most of them musical ; dealing with two rebel musicians trying to save the Catholic orphanage where they were raised by reunite their old band .Ake Blues (Dan Aykroyd) rejoins with his brother Elwood (John Belushi) after being released from prison, but the duo has just days to reunite their old R&B band , attempting to raise money enough to save an orphanage and nearly destrying Chicago in the process . While a revengeful bride (Carrie Fisher) pursues them and outrunning the police as they tear through Chicago. The most devastating team since nitro and glycerine. They'll never get caught. They're on a mission from God. They're Back. The Most Dangerous Combination Since Nitro and Glycerine. The show that really hits the road. A briefcase full of blues.One of the highest-grossing movies of all time in America and with big budget . A cataclylismic orgy of destruction , mayhem and noise . The title roles , the deadpan musical performers were introduced on Saturday Night Live TV series . It saw tubby James Belushi and splendid Dan Aykroyd shoot to stardom . They became like the adults Bud Abbott and Lou Costello of the Eighties .However , two years later Belushi was dead , from an accidental overdose of drugs . You could call it a bluesical, in fact with all the singers playing their own singing and dancing and a host of the blues legends performing through the film . The car crashing antics , too , get tiresome , but very amusing. There's a lot of singers , cameos and numerous guest stars appearing here and there , such as : James Brown , Cab Calloway , Ray Charles, Aretha Franklin , John Lee Hooker , Carrie Fisher, Henry Gibson, John Candy, John Lee Hooker, Kathleen Freeman, Twiggy, Frank Oz, Charles Napier, Steven Williams, Steven Spielberg and John Landis himself. Followed by Blues Brothers 2000 (2008) in which John Belushi is replaced by John Goodman , along with Dan Aykroyd, Joe Morton , Nia Peeples , Kathleeen Freeman , B. B. King , Frank Oz .This nutty comedy was well directed by John Landis. This great filmmaker John Landis is a notorious writer/producer/director with a long career . Landis had his period of maxim splendor in the Eighties when he directed classic comedies, such as ¨Kentucky fried movie", "Into the night", "Animal house¨ , ¨Trading Places¨and, of course, ¨Blues brothers¨. If you're into craziness and overacting of the great comical experts , John Belushi and Dan Aykroyd , this picture is for you. This entertaining and amusing film is still one of the funniest in the musical/comedy genre .

If you asked me my favourite movie, this would probably be it. They could never make another film like this, it's too over the top and nutty. We see an amazing line-up of blues performers and music -- Aretha Franklin, James Brown, Ray Charles, Cab Calloway, Sam & Dave, Steve Winwood, and the Blues Brothers band members who are all superb. The most ambitious stunts ever seen. The best comic actors including John Belushi, Dan Ackroyd, John Candy, and Henry Gibson. Even the cameos are first class, such as Twiggy, Stephen Spielberg, Frank Oz and Carrie Fisher. Just about every scene is a classic. The Nazi rally that Jake and Elwood crash into, the redneck country bar where the band performs behind chicken wire because the drunks throw bottles at them, Elwood's apartment where the trains go by non stop, and Jake and Elwood acting like pigs in a posh French restaurant in a bid to blackmail the maitre d' into coming back into the band. Yes it's a series of sketches, but the film's plot, about brothers Jake and Elwood getting their band back together to raise money to save their old orphanage, propels the film beautifully. Even the fact the band members aren't all good actors is funny. They all have a ball while sending themselves up as hapless musos roped into the Blues Brothers' crazy antics. If I had to choose a favourite scene (so hard!) it would be Ray Charles' Shake Your Tail Feather, just for Charles's joyful yet defiant playing and singing, and the way a street full of people boogies along with all those wonderful dance steps. Then at the end, Ray agrees to give Jake and Elwood the keyboard, and Ray says, ''and as usual, I gotta take an IOU''. Which is a throwaway line, but I also took it to mean, we all owe a lot, culturally, to true blues musicians like Charles. We're indebted to them, as are the Blues Brothers.

Jake Blues (John Belushi), just out from prison, puts together his old band to save the Catholic home where he and brother Elwood (Dan Aykroyd) were raised.Somehow, this film never got watched by me until now (2015). I was always aware of it, and even knew many of the film's quotes, but had never seen more than a few minutes here or there. Boy was I missing out. We start off early on with a great police chase, and by the end we have more than one (always a welcome part of any film, and sometimes the most memorable).I love the Chicago setting. Although not a Chicago native myself, it is the only big city I have spent any time in. So the suburbs are something that mean much more to me than anything shot in Los Angeles or New York. Give me McHenry or Wrigley Field any day of the week.

The "Blues Brothers" is a good comedy and a great musical, featuring James Brown, Aretha Franklin, Ray Charles and Cab Calloway as "guest" musicians (i.e., not members of the BB). The BB band is composed of excellent musicians such as Lou Marini, Alan Rubin and Donald "Duck" Dunn among others. One interesting aspect of the movie I haven't read about in other reviews (so far) concerns spoofs of other movies and TV shows. For instance, when Jake gets out of prison he walks through a blinding white light and out the gate, reminiscent of the kidnapped earthlings disembarking from the giant UFO near the end of "Close Encounters." The interview with the "Penguin" (walking up a long flight of stairs, and the Penguin floating back into the room) is a spoof on "The Exorcist." Jake and Elwod's interview with the landlady is a spoof on the old TV show "Dragnet." The car chase under the El spoofs "The French Connection" car chase and even uses several seconds of footage from the movie. The scene in which a police dispatcher authorizes "the use of excessive force to apprehend the Blue Brothers" spoofs the old TV show "Highway Patrol" and I believe the movie dispatcher was in the TV show as well. I'm not quite sure how the Nazis chasing our heroes is a spoof of "Apocalypse Now" but the music (Wagner's "Flight of the Valkyries") in this sequence was used in both films. I susect there are more spoofs of other movies and/or TV shows present that I'm missing; if anyone out there can name more I'd like to know about them as well.

Having somehow never watched 'The Blues Brothers' in the last thirty four years, I set out to rectify that oversight with certain preconceptions in mind.I more or less knew the plot, as one cannot immerse themselves in pop culture the way my generation has and not pick these things up, so I was expecting the humor and the high energy musical numbers. What surprised me were the over the top car chase scenes, the quirky, askew tone and the general excess. All of this most certainly gives the film its unique charm, but at a bloated 132 minutes, it's ultimately a bit numbing.

reviews.review_title: Two White Guys Sing The Blues
reviews.content:
Did "The Blues Brothers" introduce millions of white Americans to the African-American art form of the blues? Factually, that's maybe tough to argue with. Over forty years later, is it regrettable that a blues band fronted by two white guys had to serve as its catalyst for crossing over into the larger conversation?Hindsight is always 20/20, and 1980 was the proverbial different world back then, but with the possible exception of similarly stark-white blues champions The Rolling Stones, one could argue that no musical or cinematic vehicle has so successfully introduced the brilliance of an underrepresented art form to such a massive crossover audience. Granted, there's no question that bits of "The Blues Brothers" now feel like we're watching something being borrowed and worn from someone else's closet (see: the church and street market scenes). Then again, there's also little question that Dan Aykroyd and John Belushi are lovingly entrenched in these transformative tunes (they started the Blues Brothers band before the film took shape, and it was loaded with African-American blues legends). Nor is it in doubt that this music comedy almost singularly kicked in the door to allow an army of descendant films to pour in.Perhaps there's an argument that "The Blues Brothers" has become even more engrossing today because of these nuanced dynamics. Play it loud and let's find out. - (Was this review of use to you? If so, let me know by clicking "Helpful." Cheers!)
-

"Stadium Anthems (2018)," "Sausage Party (2016)," "South Park: Bigger, Longer & Uncut (1999)."

reviews.review_title: "They're not gonna catch us. We're on a mission from God."
reviews.content: Jake Blues (John Belushi) is released from prison and reunites with his brother Elwood (Dan Aykroyd). The brothers discover the orphanage in which they grew up in is about to be closed unless they can raise the money to keep it open. So they go on a "mission from God" to put their old band back together and throw a big concert to raise the money.Highly entertaining comedy with some kick-ass music. This was John Landis' first great movie, in my opinion. Belushi and Aykroyd are wonderful. The supporting cast is first-rate. How about that car chase? Really makes today's CGI music video choreographed car stunts look like excrement. A fun movie made by people who clearly enjoy what they're doing. An '80s classic everybody should see at least once.

THE BLUES BROTHER is one of those movies that gets highly praised in reviews in TV guides and the like , and it does have a hardcore following . In fact I remember seeing the rather poor WAR OF THE WORLDS TV series from the 1980S that has a scene with the martians walking into a Blues Brother convention ! But to be honest I vaguely remember hating this movie the first time I saw it many years ago and watched it again last night to see if it was as bad as I remembered Jake is released from prison and his brother Elwood comes to pick him up in a second hand police car and the opening sequences seem to drag on . Considering THE BLUES BROTHERS is supposed to be a musical comedy there`s a complete absence of either music or comedy . Later on we do get musical numbers and there is some uplifting moments especially with the Ray Charles number . However with most musicals the segments featuring singing and dancing are set pieces that don`t fit into the narrative easily . There`s also a wider problem with the movie and that is it has no real narrative shape . All through the movie characters and incidents happen as if it seemed like a good idea at the time so by the end we have a chaotic embarrasing mess as troops , fire engines , policemen and SWAT teams chase after Jake and Elwood . In many ways THE BLUES BROTHERS is very similar to the Bond spoof CASINO ROYALE with sometimes memorable musical interludes amidst self indulgent and oh so painfully self indulgent comedy set pieces

First, there isn't a person in existence who can't enjoy good soul music, if you find one they'll like jazz. And if that doesn't work, I'm not talking R&B when I say rhythm and blues.Second, only Groucho Marx could honestly say that he's got a wit sharper than that with which this was written.Third, Illinois Nazis headed by Henry Gibson. Fourth, "We're on a mission from God."Fifth, More police cars are destroyed in this movie than in the history of automobiles. Sixth, The hardest working man in show business, The godfather of soul, The Reverend Cleophus James Brown.Seventh, Police chase after police chase after police chase.Eighth, "This is car number fifty-five, we're in a truck!"Ninth, S.C.M.O.D.S. State County Municipal Offender Data SystemTenth, You will not have a backside after this film because you will have laughed it off.

The Blues Brothers is not only a wonderful comedy but a tremendous musical. Along with the comedic pairing of Akroyd and Belushi there are plenty of comedians sprinkled throughout the film one of which being John Candy in a minor role. This film also has a slew of blues and jazz musicians playing cameo roles in the film. The plot is a fairly basic one, the Blues Brothers gotta save the orphanage from the tax collectors by getting the band back together and putting on a show that will get them the money to pay the taxes and their debts, all while making numerous enemies that ends with a giant chase for the Brothers Blue. What makes this film not only unique but iconic is the performances of both actors and musicians making for an enjoyable film. This movie is a must see not only for fans of the SNL skits but for lovers of film in general.

Jake Blues (John Belushi) just got released from prison. He and brother Elwood (Dan Aykroyd) reluctantly goes to visit The Penguin. The nun tells them that the orphanage needs to pay $5000 for back taxes in 11 days. She won't take any ill gotten money so the only option is to get the band back together. They are on a mission from God. Meanwhile, a mysterious woman (Carrie Fisher) keeps trying to kill Jake.Dan Aykroyd and John Landis have created two iconic comedic characters. It's a whole lot of craziness. Landis basically throws everything into the movie. It mostly works. There are also great musicians involved. It is a bit too long. Over 2 hours is not a good running time for a comedy. It's hard to maintain the level of comedy for that long and some sections are less funny than needed. It needs some tightening to intensify the comedy.

Taking part in a best films of 1980 poll,I decided to check titles on Netflix UK from the year. Having read praise for the movie over the years,I got set to finally meet the brothers.View on the film:Originally starting as a 324 page script that Dan Aykroyd planned to be a two-part film, (overstuffing his initial scripts being a recurring issue with Aykroyd's ideas) which the director ended up spending three weeks trimming down, the resulting final version by Aykroyd and John Landis is a hilarious Blues-drenched Road Movie, where Elwood and Jake have everyone from the cops,to a Country and Western band chasing them down.Whilst having to be picky over how truthful they are in their attempt to get the band back together, the writers give the dead-pan duo a playful heart for redemption, via linking the pit-stops the recently released from jail duo make, to a overarching plot line of their actions being based around attempts by the brothers to save their former Catholic orphanage from closing.Igniting the closing 30 minutes with a thrilling epic final chase set-piece, ( 103 cars were wrecked during filming) director Landis continues to build on a ease of taking Comedy into a detour of other genres, which would lead to his next film An American Werewolf in London (1981).Closely working with Switchblade Sisters (1975-also reviewed) cinematographer Stephen M. Katz, Landis has Jake and Elwood (played with a very funny upright swagger by John Belushi & Dan Aykroyd) Landis drives the brothers from in hot water buddy Comedy antics and flamboyant toe-tapping song and dance numbers, to white-knuckle action,as the brothers get the blues.

reviews.review_title: This movie is amazing in just about every way.
reviews.content: The Blues Brothers (1980) is a movie that I recently watched for the first time in a long time on Tubi. The storyline follows two brothers, including one recently released from prison, who are looking to put their band back together, go on tour, and delivers soulful blues music. They will be aided along the way but find their rise to stardom more challenging than they game planned for...This movie is directed by John Landis (Animal House) and stars John Belushi (Animal House), Dan Aykroyd (Ghostbusters), John Candy (Armed and Dangerous), Paul Reubens (Pee-Wee's Playhouse) and Carrie Fisher (Star Wars).This movie is amazing in just about every way. Belushi and Aykroyd are perfectly selected as the blues brothers and deliver charismatic performances and characters easy to root for. Landis did a great job of working legends in for cameos and performances throughout the movie to give it the appropriate look and feel - Ray Charles, Aretha Franklin, James Brown, De'voreaux White and John Lee Hooker, among others. There are so many classic scenes in this - the pick-up from the prison, the scene with the nun at the orphanage, the performance at the bar, etc. Every scene they perform their songs is a treat and the car in this is legendary.Overall, this is an underrated masterpiece and a great movie about music. I would score this a 9/10 and strongly recommend it.

"It's 106 miles to Chicago. We've got a full tank of gas, half a pack of cigarettes, it's dark, and we're wearing sunglasses." - Elwood. "Hit it." - Jake.Director John Landis can make a great movie out of the most simplistic premises. After working with the late John Belushi on National Lampoon's Animal House in 1978, he returns to give us the funny, satirical, wickedly hilarious Blues Brothers. At first glance, the blend of music and comedy may throw many off, but if you're willing to go back to a time when movies were movies, The Blues Brothers is quite a throwback.The film's greatest accomplishment stems from its unlimited energy and desire to have fun. Jake and Elwood (played by Dan Akroyd and John Belushi) are one of the most enigmatic duos who ever made it on the big screen, and provide inseparable chemistry especially when at the mic. Even when they aren't at the mic, they are either doing some of the funniest fight sequences or claiming to yet another strange they're on a mission from God.A formal storyline is almost nonexistent. It's best to just go along for the ride. After getting out of the big house for an armed robbery, "Joliet" Jake is forced by his brother Elwood to go see a nun at their old home. They both learn that the orphanage will be closed if they do not pay their dues; $5,000 in property taxes. Ultimately, Jake gets the genius idea to reform their old rhythm and blues band. From there on out spawns a sea of insanity and a never-ending line of one liners.The Blues Brothers is lengthy and about twenty minutes could've been set on the scrap floor. But the execution is near perfect. There are two car chases that could very well rank in some of the best ever executed in film. Police cars topple each other, one after another, and the film knows when to start and when to end them.Fun not only stems from the enigmatic protagonists, but the extremely well acted music numbers. The theme from Rawhide, the classic ladies-hit "Think," and even that hometown classic of "Sweet Home Chicago" are all played ecstatically throughout the film. They surely won't get out of your head anytime soon after hearing them.The Blues Brothers is a fun, energized comedy that starts fast and rarely lets up in terms of comedy and music. It's a Chicago classic and one of the funniest and smartest musical comedies I have yet to see.By the way, how do you knock a film that has two lead characters on a mission from God? Starring: Dan Akroyd and John Belushi. Directed by: John Landis.

This film isn't completely a comedy, but it is fun.  Dan Aykroyd and the late, great John Belushi make this film watchable by bringing back the blues (despite it being a incredible sacrilege for white guys to play the blues). Not an instant classic, but one that becomes a classic with time. Directed by John Landis, who brings some good things to the film including as a co-writer (along with first time writer Aykroyd).  Cameos include James Brown, Aretha Franklin, Frank Oz, Steven Spielberg, Landis, Ray Charles, Johhny Lee Hooker, and Paul Reubens.  A-

Those sneaky film makers. Here's a movie starring John Belushi, of Bluto fame in Animal House, and Dan Aykroyd as two bums who lead a blues revue band who try to outrun the police and is the cause of many car wrecks, and it's a musical!!! Men aren't supposed to like musicals, yet here is one that any man, and women, especially those who have any positive feel for rhythm and blues music, will enjoy this film. It's funny, involves things blowing up, men in tacky Western outfits, and features many outstanding performances by great R&B singers. Ray Charles, Aretha Franklin, James Brown, and Cab Calloway all lend their great musical talents to this otherwise fun movie about two guys who dress alike who want to raise money for their former orphanage. To do so, they reunite with their former blues band, one they left to serve time in jail. After a rocky first outing at a country bar, one with chicken wire to protect the band, they are able to get one more gig at a hotel outside of Chicago. Everything is all set, that is except their car runs out of gas. It's little moments like that where the movie succeeds, where it is funniest, and where the considerable talents of Belushi and Aykroyd come through and shine. Carrie Fischer plays a crazed ex-wife of one of the Blues Brothers, i suppose in a break from her Princess Leia past, and look for Frank Oz and Steven Spielberg in small, yet noticeable roles. Music, cars crashing, and humor carry this musical into the "success" category.

reviews.review_title: Please dont use common sense while watching this absurd music comedy, because it is DELIBERATELY simplistic and silly. Enjoyable nonetheless.
reviews.content: Crazy silly story, but very enjoyable nonetheless. John Belushi and Dan Akroyd wanna bring THE BAND together again to raise money to save an orphanage from closing. Unfortunately this band gets into trouble with the law and what follows is without a doubt the most outrageous police chase. Even if you cant enjoy the very beginning of the movie please do give the last half an hour a try, because it is truly hilarious with the most bizarre and hilarious car chase in the history of american cinema. Filmed back in the days when there were no cgi or computer effects, so all the cars that crash are REAL crashes. I assure you, that truly enhances the fun A LOT!Besides this legendary car chase the music alone makes this movie worth watching: music performances and acting by Ray Charles, John Lee Hooker, James Brown, Arehta Franklin. These are all music legends. Amazing that director John Landis pulled it off to get all those stars into 1 flick like this.There is also a funny appearance at the very end by none other than Steven Spielberg, who never acts in any picture, but did so this time around."The Blues Brothers" gained a cult status decades ago. A cult status doesnt necessarily mean it is a masterpiece, it isnt, but the movie just struck a chord for many weirdos back in the eighties. Music bands have been formed which were inspired by this movie. Special Blues Brothers movie screenings are still regularly being held worldwide, to honor this absurd yet classic music road movie. At those festive blues brothers nights everybody goes wild with booze and drugs. Books have been written about John Landis' cult film. Documentaries have been made to analyse it. It has become bigger than anyone could have imagined back then...But please dont use common sense while watching this absurd music comedy. It does help if you are drunk (or stoned or both), when watching this movie, because it is DELIBERATELY simplistic and silly. Very enjoyable and hilarious nonetheless...

I must say straight up that this musical 'comedy' just ain't my scene. Jake and Elwood Blues are on a mission from God - which finds them on the run from the law, neo-Nazis, redneck country bands and aggrieved ex-fiancées. In order to save their Catholic boys home from closure, the guys decide to put 'the band' back together after 'seeing the light'. What follows is a state wide scramble as the guys gather the old crew together while always narrowly avoiding capture.Writers Dan Aykroyd and John Landis' offbeat script, which is part time slapstick and part time satire, really fails for me as a comedy. Their dialogue is incredibly dry and sardonic, but so much so it's parched. The best laugh on offer is probably the mall scene in which Jake and Elwood drive around the local shopping centre doing a spot of casual window shopping, while the police are in hot pursuit.The catchy musical numbers are what saves the film, with some rhythm and blues being matched with some smart, wacky choreography. Contributing to this soul-fest are some of the all time greats including Cab Calloway, Aretha Franklin, James Brown, Ray Charles, John Lee Hooker and the Blues Brothers band. The cast of actors do a reasonable job, with Aykroyd and John Belushi (obviously enjoying themselves) being backed up by Carrie Fisher, John Candy, Henry Gibson, Frank Oz, Charles Napier, Jeff Morris, Kathleen Freeman and Twiggy.Stephen M. Katz captures the action with skill and Ira Newborn supplies the incidental music.Saturday, September 14, 1996 - Video

Ok, so it's not really a family movie, but it's my family's movie. I didn't grow up in Chicago, but grew up close enough to know and love the town, it's spots, sports teams and everything else that this quintessential Chicago movie is near and dear to my heart, as well as the rest of my family's. 
Ok no, it's not a perfect movie, there are some very silly scenes, there's a sort of spiritual and supernatural element that is somewhat overlooked that seems oddly out of place, but it's all woven together so well by John Landis, and the comedy is so palpable that, while others movies would be dragged down, this one gets a pass. The goofball stuff actually boosts the movie in my opinion. And lest I forget to mention the music is timeless and fantastic, as are the stars and guest stars who bring it to us. A who's who of soul and the original R&B, with "a sound powerful enough to turn goat piss into gasoline!"

reviews.review_title: Hilarious Movie with a Brilliant Cast and Great Soundtrack,
reviews.content: The Blues Brothers is a fantastic movie with a very well developed plot and a very talented comedic cast. The chemistry between Dan Aykroyd and John Belushi is without a doubt the highlight of this film, the two of them were clearly very close friends and were very interested in their characters, Jake and Elwood. They deliver top notch performances as these characters that think their a lot more threatening and suspicious than they actually are.The only thing that disappointed me was how little we learn about either Jake or Elwood throughout the film, I understand that they wanted to leave a bit of mystery to them, but I felt the story would have been far more engaging had we known more about the brothers as people prior to heading on this journey. The music in this film is also great, there is not a single song I did not enjoy. They are all very catchy and the amazing musicians they got in this movie to play some of the songs, as well as Aykroyd and Belushi themselves. are outstanding.It is a simple, straight forward and fun film that you can switch your brain off whilst viewing and simply have a good time. The Blues Brothers is a great movie that I would recommend to anyone looking for a great comedy or musical.Two brothers, Jake and Elwood Blues, must bring their old band back together in order to save the orphanage they grew up in from shutting down.Best Performance: John Belushi

reviews.review_title: Ex Saturday Night Live = bad movie
reviews.content: This film has it good moment, and a few comedy classic scenes.  The music part of this film is like eating glass.  They forced the old SNL blues skit into the film.  One see John Candy in a bit part, and  Steven Spielberg only acting role. (tax office guy) Over rated and out dated. 4/10

reviews.review_title: This film never, ever fails to disappoint.
reviews.content: A film that, in my opinion, has it all. A star studded line up that can actually act and not just attract celebrity-hunters, incredible chase scenes, witty one-liners that do not border on the verge of malignance and some of the best songs ever written.After watching this film over 30 times, it honestly never fails to disappoint.John Belushi and Dan Akroyd work so well together, and really act as if they are their characters, as opposed to actors paid to be them. And car chase scenes that would make Minis salivate, and an array of side plots that work so seamlessly with the "Mision from God".The on-screen chemistry between the band is frictionated and therefore completely accurate for anyone who has been in a group, but when the music starts, always a guaranteed classic throughout the film, then the magic of the film really happens.A film that borders genius and then creates a whole new country, and one that may be re-attempted, but never rivalled.

reviews.review_title: Not my thing, but a fine comedy for those that appreciate its humour
reviews.content: I will preface this by saying that I'm really picky about comedies. I'm more of a sarcasm and black comedy kind of guy so I rarely encounter a comedy that I really like.That being said, this is a neat little film. Built around the personalities of John Belushi and Dan Aykroyd and their sketch characters Jake and Elwood, it's a twisting and turning journey to save an orphanage that they both grew up in. On their trip they gather allies, make enemies, play some gorgeous music and generally get into trouble.So what works? Well, the music for one. Most of the musicians playing in Jake and Elwood's band are actual, real life jazz and blues musicians and you can believe that they can actually play. Heck, even Belushi and Aykroyd are actual musicians, so whenever a musical number starts, the movie instantly picks up in quality. Furthermore, the film has some good appreciation for physical humour, long and imaginative chase scenes and the rough Chicago style world of blues looks kind of fetching.Unfortunately it's meant to be a comedy and I never really found it all that funny. The main joke is supposed to be that Jake and Elwood are never really bothered by anything, and it... kind of works? If straight man humour is your thing, I'm sure you'll be laughing your ass off. If it's not, the movie falls flat pretty quickly. There's some enjoyment to be found in the action-oriented jokes and in the general blight of these two bums, but you have to find Jake and Elwood funny for you to enjoy this film.Still, it's a fine movie. The music is great, the general story is not bad, it's well acted and it looks good. Give it a chance and I'm sure you'll find something in it to enjoy.

John Landis just got to have the credit for making this movie a big hit. "The Blues Brothers" is musically funny, and such a thrill to enjoy. Here you got Jake Blues(John Belushi, 1949-82) and his brother Elwood(Dan Ackroyd) who are sent on a "mission from God" to build up the Band and save the orphanage from being sold. Jake is out on parole from a Joliet,Ill. prison, Elwood drives a old Dodge Police Car , and they carry their mission along the way. They would run afoul of the State Police, Neo-Nazis, a Country & Western band, and a woman(Carrie Fisher) who was jilted by Jake. While trying to make friends, they make enemies as well. The car chase scenes are a classic, the State Police and The Chicago Police were after the Blues. High speeds and sirens can be deafening, yet in this movie, it's all fun. Not only them, the Fire Dept., The National Guard, and S.W.A.T. came after the Blues, right after the car died. That mission was not to be interrupted by anyone, or anything. The cast members of the movie was great: James Brown, Ray Charles, John Lee Hooker, Cab Calloway, Aretha Franklin, etc. I mean it was great! A huge keeper here. 5 stars! for star power!

(Flash Review)The Blues Brothers need to raise $5K, in 11 days, to help a nun pay rent on her church building they were raised at. After one of the Blues Brothers is released from prison, they set out to get their disbanded band back together to earn the $5k. Many hijinks revolve around them persuading the band members to rejoin and also finding gigs to earn money. Peppy musical numbers sporadically pop up with a wide spectrum of songs; more than just blues. This did a nice job of blending good comedy into a substantial story with the help of a slew of SNL characters from the era. It also had surprisingly quality cinematography for the era and genre. The may have destroyed more cop cars than the Dukes of Hazzard did over a couple seasons. So that was fun and Carry Fisher played a very unusual character. Almost out of place for the story and maybe hinting at her Princess Lea alter ego.

reviews.review_title: Best comedy duo ever!! Underrated team and movie!!!
reviews.content: This is such a rare thing to see and to be able to own it and watch this MASTERPIECE of comedy AND a musical!! For a loosey 30.00 I should be arrested for buying this so cheap!! And in 4k ultra...seriously!! Anyway nothing you can say that hasn't been said about this movie and this magical duo, if John would have dodged his addiction they would have been the next laurel and hardy!! Only better if that's even possible!!

reviews.review_title: How someone could possibly rate this a 10 is ...impossible
reviews.content: Humor is subjective, beauty is in the eye of the beholder, opinions and tastes, etc etc... but say what you want, I'm just baffled, confounded and stunned some would have the ability in them to rate this a 10.This thing is atrociously thick, in bad taste the whole way, utterly and awfully obvious, unsubtle, slow, dense to a rare degree. It's so unconvincing scene after scene after scene it really is, if anything at all, an exercise in trying the very hardest to pretend like everything isn't terribly overdone and thick and a pitiful shell of what it's trying to accomplish, and trying to find a rhythm in one's self to go along with it.It's so, so very terribly thick and slow and obvious, I'm running out of adjectives or even descriptive statements. There's nothing more to say, in truth.Really just bad stuff. The fans can only be extremely dedicated fanatics of the theme, genre or actors, because this is just the very definition of a self-indulgent comedy that's barely trying at all.

reviews.review_title: X10 Better Than West Side Story
reviews.content: This is the musical to watch. It is musical, it is hilarious, it kills Illinois Nazis dead, features loser pis and even has Princess Leia armed, ready and dangerous.John Landis really hit a home-run with this one.The loser hillbillies (like The Nazis) look like they just came from a MAGA rally to perform at a MAGA saloon.

Do I really need to put my two cents in on one of the all-time "classics"? Hasn't this been talked about to death already? I was coerced into seeing this movie I never, ever wanted to see from a friend that said I wasn't a movie-lover (I am) if I've never seen this. And when I plugged in the movie and saw it was 2½ hours, for a movie I'm not that invested in, I began questioning our friendship. For the first hour or so, I chuckled a little, though it did keep my interest. Then, BAM, it seemed to take off and I got giggly for the rest of the extremely fun and funny ride. One thing that shocked me was: how much faith they had in a five-(or less)-minute sketch on SNL. They must've had this huge budget – blowing up buildings, destroying malls – and the length was far too long. Butat the same time, that was the biggest problem: it was far too long and it took far too long to get going. That said, it was thoroughly worth the journey of the men in black once it did build steam – especially from the comic genius John Belushi (check out the fantastic nonchalantly they handle the out-of-left-field situations they find themselves in) and the "guest appearances," my favorite of which was, believe it, Carrie Fisher. The funniest segment, that made me pause it since I was laughing so hard, was the soaring cars in the climax. 4/5 Stars.

I've always felt this movie was extremely overrated by fans of SNL at the time. By the time the movie came out, people were so in love with the whole Blues Brothers phenomenon on SNL, that it really wouldn't take too much of a quality movie to capitalize upon that. The script, which included some of the most idiotic chase scenes in cinema history, seems like it was written in a single night of chemical indulgence. By the time you get to the end of the movie, you get the feeling that John Landis knew the movie wasn't really working - so he decided to just make the scale of the chase scene completely ridiculous in order to try and make someone laugh at something.The music numbers are what saves the movie from being a complete failure. They're so good that they will make you forget about just how stupid the rest of the movie actually is. Side note : I think it's worth noting that John Landis is completely overrated in himself. Sure, he directed "Animal House", and "American Werewolf In London". But, his failures FAR outweigh his successes. Just to name some of his other flops : "Spies Like Us", "Three Amigos", "Oscar", "Beverly Hills Cop 3", and of course "Blues Brothers 2000". I've always felt that "Trading Places" could probably have been a better movie with a different director.

reviews.review_title: Funniest, funkiest, coolest film on the planet
reviews.content: I guess it must be an age thing, but at 40 myself and my peers often find ourselves quoting Jake and Elwood.  'Would you like to come out for like, er, a date'; 'I hate Illinois Nazis'; '..get a new cigarette lighter'.In isolation these quotes don't make any sense, but in situ they are classic lines by the masters that are Belushi and Ackroyd.  This is a film paying homage to some of the best music ever made, that steals classic comic performances from Aretha Franklin and Ray Charles and if I am not mistaken beats Michael Jackson to the punch by a mile with a massive group dance using the 'chicken' (the zombie dance in the Thriller video is a direct copy of the dance routine in the street while BB King is performing on the sidewalk, wearing incredible shoes).This is a film that every house should own.  Not only is it extremely funny due to script, timing from the Bro's and quite frankly the total sex that is John Belushi, it is also heaving with classic tunes.  I have often had/been to parties where it is played in the background rather than putting the record/tape/CD player on (parties through the ages).As an education in how to put music and comic genius together to make a film that is timeless this is it.Let me give you an example.  I spent three years in South Africa as an expat from 1993 - 1996 and, of course, had this film on video (age again) as part of my collection.SA is a sociable place and often new found friends from office, pub etc. would collect at my house for a meal (almost always a Braai).  "What's this?" one such person says one evening as I am tossing food on the barbecue, "I've never heard of the Blues Brothers".  "Put it on" I say, with quizzical looks from other guests that the TV should be switched on while we are out in the garden.  "and turn the volume up".Rest history.  20 Captownians turned on to music they were never allowed to hear, gravitating indoors to see where it is coming from and then screaming with laughter while they danced in front of the TV.This film, in my experience has changed lives.Buy it, watch it, tell your children.

reviews.review_title: One of the best films of all time, I have watched it so many times
reviews.content:
I have watched this film so many tines and I never get tired of it.
I showed the kids some clips of the car chase scenes including the demise of the Nazis and they loved it.
The language and some other content not quite right for them yet but they will get a full showing some day soon.The story is hilarious, the outrageous car chases are fantastic and the music is great, including cameos from many famous artists

There are many movies listed as "must see" for film fans. The Blues Brothers is one of those movies listed as a must see. Oftentimes, even if I don't see the draw to one of these must-see films after I see it, I will at least understand the hype; I do not see the hype with The Blues Brothers. The 1980 film directed by John Landis starring Dan Aykroyd and John Belushi tells the tale of a set of brothers on a mission from God to raise money for and save the Catholic home in which they were raised. The best way they can think of to accomplish this goal is to get back together the band they used to play in and donate the money to the home. Aided by a myriad of musical stars throughout the film, The Blues Brothers turns out to be an extended music video sequence rather than a cohesive film.Jake 'Joliet' Blues (John Belushi) has just been released from prison to the care of his brother Elwood Blues (Dan Aykroyd). Jake promised to visit "The Penguin" (Kathleen Freeman) on the first day of his release. "The Penguin" was one of the nuns who raised them through childhood in the Catholic boarding school in which they lived. During their visit, they are told that the boarding school's funding has been cut and will no longer be able to sustain itself unless they are able to secure $5000.00 in 11 days. Feeling compelled, The Blues Brothers decide to help, but given their collective aversion to law abiding, obtaining the money honestly will prove to be the biggest problem. Finally, divine intervention hits and the two decide to reform the band they used to play in, host a couple concerts, and donate the money to the boarding school. Elwood, however, has not held up his part of the bargain of maintaining contact with the rest of the band members while Jake was in prison. The two must now go on an adventure to find the band members, who have since all taken straight jobs, in order to be able to play the concerts. Their adventure ruffles a few feathers along the way and it becomes much more of a race against time to achieve their mission from God than the two thought it would be.I had always disregarded this film as a frivolous film based on a popular Saturday Night Live skit, thinking that there can't be much more to it than that, after seeing it, I found out I was mostly right. I'm not a fan of SNL, so perhaps I would have gained more out of the film if I was familiar and enjoyed the skit it was based on. There was just so much more bad than good in this film. The pacing was unbelievably slow. A solid 45-minutes of this film could have been cut at a favorable service to the audience. The amazing thing is that throughout the slow, tedious pacing of the film, the character development was incredibly deficient. I never learned enough to care about either of the brothers or their "mission from God". The chemistry between Aykroyd and Belushi was fantastic, one can tell that the two were truly great friends. Good chemistry does not good acting make, however. I struggle to even call what the two did acting as they were more focused on appearing "cool" than portraying anything. There were some redeeming qualities to the film. I was ignorant to the fact that John Landis directed the film until his credit rolled up at the beginning of the movie. I quite like some of his work and the incredible shots that I loved in his American Werewolf in London, were also present in The Blues Brothers. I couldn't believe how gorgeous this film looked, from the long shot up the stairs when the brothers visit "The Penguin" to the opening sequence of Jake being released from prison, the film is stuffed to the brim with amazing shots. The car chases, as ridiculous as they were, gave some enjoyment to an otherwise lackluster film. One can't adequately rate The Blues Brothers without mentioning the amazing musicians that took part in the project. Some notable names who lent their voices to this film include Ray Charles, Aretha Franklin, James Brown, and Cab Calloway. Clearly, musical talent was in no short supply for The Blues Brothers, and it is the music, in fact, that saves the film. Other than great music and wonderful shots, however, The Blues Brothers remains a gimmicky film (glasses through the entire film, really?) that I cannot, for the life of me, understand why it enjoys the status that it does.

reviews.review_title: Great, the best movie to come out from a Saturday Night Live skit
reviews.content: The Blues Brothers is a great movie with brilliant comedy director John Landis behind the screen and the winning team of John Belushi and Dan Aykroyd in front of the screen. Belushi and Aykroyd are on mission from God to get the band back together to raise money to save the Catholic orphanage they grew up in. The film looks great and there are a lot of legit musical legends like James Brown, Aretha Franklin, Cab Calloway, Ray Charles and John Lee Hooker that not only provide good tunes, but gives The Blues Brothers serious musical credibility. The supporting cast is memorable as well, especially Carrie Fisher(who looks amazing in this) and John Candy. The car chase scenes are done really well and The Blues Brothers really holds up as a really fun and cool movie. It is no surprise that this turned out to be a big hit and has a large cult following that continues to exist today.
We are on the mission from GOD. This legen dary movie is a must see for every one. A feel good movie has a lot of music and good fun. For anyone to enjoy, great fun, great success!

I just rented the extended version, and was reminded of what a landmark, memorable film this really is. Sure, some of the car crash stuff is a bit over the top, but this film really is a rare documentary of some of the great blues and R&B artists of the later part of the 20th century.One part in the extended version I particularly enjoyed was an expanded scene with the late, great John Lee Hooker on a semi-fictionalized version of Maxwell street, which has since been rehabbed and is now upscale housing, just south of Chicago's University of Illinois Circle campus. (If you look closely, you can see a sign for Esquire J-Town Clothing for Men and Boys..."J-Town" being a slightly more politically correct way of saying "Jew Town", a nickname for Maxwell street from way back). Anyway, John Lee is doing his thing accompanied by several members of Muddy Waters' blues band, plus the very colorful Big Walter Horton on harp. Before entering Aretha Franklin's diner, Jake and Elwood are just taking in the scene, and I gotta believe that John and Dan (the alter egos) were really enjoying themselves at that moment.As a musical comedy, I don't think anything came close during that time. While some critics were not happy with what they considered gratuitous exploitation of R&B giants like James Brown and Ray Charles, I for one am happy that someone like John Landis captured something as "cool" as Cab Calloway performing "Minnie the Moocher" with the very accomplished Blues Brothers band.If you can't have fun with this movie, you just ain't much fun.

When the Blues Brothers begins, you'd swear it was a drama. IT starts with a very slow Kurosawa type scene (wide shots, no music, hardly any dialogue). In this scene Jake Blues is getting out of the joint. His brother Elwood picks him up. The first place they go is to visit the orphanage where they grew up. It is going out of business, and so the two go on a quest to raise the money to save the place. First they have to reform their old band, and then find a gig, a very big gig.In addition to featuring some of the funniest people of the decade, We also have Aretha Franklin, James Brown, and Ray Charles. We have lots of bottles getting thrown around, lots of glass getting smashed, rockets being launched, cars getting wrecked, and next thing you know half the US military is being sent out to take down a mere two nitwits, who are simply on a mission to do a good dead. This is an utterly goofy, and pretty darn lovable movie. Evern the music numbers are not too bad.The whole formula feels like Mel Brooks meets SNL, meets the soul/blues station. It's a little too mature to be a family comedy, (unless your youngest is over twelve). But it is a really fun film to watch, and has something to offer for (almost) everyone.

The Blues Brothers is a classic. It's such a Chicago icon that there are statues of Jake Blues (John Belushi) and Elwood Blues (Dan Akroyd) there. The story is crazy and so over the top that the best way for me to explain it is that Jake, just out of prison and his brother Elwood have to get the band back together to raise money to save the orphanage where they grew up and inadvertently become the most wanted men in the United States. Don't ask how this is, just watch the movie. It's funny, it's quirky, it's well acted, the guest stars are great fun, it's just great. The one word that pops into my head when I hear Blues Brothers is fun. This is just a fun movie. Nine stars. Go check it out.

There's plenty of music in this comedy spin-off from a "Saturday Night Live" TV skit with Dan Aykroyd and John Belushi, in which Jake Blues and his brother Elwood put together a band to save the Catholic home in Chicago where they were raised. In addition to some fine numbers by the brothers, this movie features plenty of classics: "Hold On! I'm Comin'" by Sam and Dave, "Think" performed by Aretha Franklin, "I'm Walkin'" by Fats Domino, and "Jailhouse Rock performed by the Blues Brothers with Franklin, James Brown, Cab Calloway, and Ray Charles. ---from Musicals on the Silver Screen, American Library Association, 2013
It has a funny storyline and is overall just very enjoyable.The actors fit the characters perfectly and the funny nature of the movie is greatly mixed with the rational reasoning behind the story.

The Emagine Willow Creek movie theater near me runs a monthly "Secret Cinema", hosted by a local movie critic.  You don't know what the film is until it starts but they alternate from a "Classic" (Citizen Kane, Singin' in the Rain) to a "Modern Classic" (Dr. Strangelove, Fargo).  So this month, the "Secret Cinema" was...THE BLUES BROTHERSThis John Belushi/Dan Ackroyd (directed by John Landis) joint from 1980 has grown in stature since it's debut 37 years ago and watching it with fresh eyes on the big screen (and 37 years older than my 19 year old self) has certainly given me a different appreciation of this film.Rather than this being an "above average" comedy, with some pretty good car chases and crashes, this film holds up as an homage to the great Blues talents of the past.  Ackroyd and Belushi were determined to get some of the greats on screen - and they succeeded.  Ray Charles and Aretha Franklin show up and "do their thing" - and they do it well.  But, for me, the highlight was seeing John Lee Hooker as a street musician and the great Cab Calloway doing "Minnie the Moocher" (hi- dee, hi-dee, hi-dee, hi), I am glad these performances have been captured for posterity.And...of course...the Blue Brothers Band is a "who's who" of Blues musicians of the time - "Blue Lou" Marini, Steve Cropper, Donald "Duck" Dunn and Matt "Guitar" Murphy were welcome sites and Ackroyd and Belushi more than held their own on the musical side of things - especially during my favorite musical number - the "Theme from Rawhide" number at the country bar.It's a good thing the music is good for the plot of this film is flimsy (at best) really just put together to get from musical number to musical number, populated with some fun cameos:  John Candy, Carrie Fisher, Artie Gibson (as a Nazi!), Kathleen Freeman, Frank Oz and even Steven Spielberg all get in on the fun, trying hard to keep up with Ackroyd and Belushi in their prime.Complementing this is some of the "funnest" auto chases and crashes in movie cinema history.  It is said that Director Landis has stated that this film sets the record for most cars crashed in a film - and I can believe it.  Car after car after car is demolished as the Brothers complete their quest.An interesting entry in the "Secret Cinema" series.  Certainly one that I wouldn't have chosen, but that's the beauty of this series - it forces me to revisit films on the big screen that I wouldn't normally check out. I can't wait for next month's entry.  In the meantime, check out THE BLUES BROTHERS on line (or watch for it to show up on cable - it is there often).Letter Grade:  right on the border between A-/B+8 (out of 10) stars and you can take that to the Bank (OfMarquis)

I love John Belushi. I love Dan Akroyd. So these two put together should have made an explosive movie. What happened instead? The 2 actors played the whole movie with sunglasses and had only one expression: being cool. Get lost! OK so there are some good car chases and some good musical numbers. But what about the rest of the movie which by the way lasts more than 2 hours? I can't stand the site of these 2 actors that never crack a joke and are never funny because they are too busy having that cool look. What a waist of talent.In this movie everything is detached. There is no amalgam between the scenes, as if the movie was just many clips put together. The DVD is quite bad. Bad colors and bad light. I will remember John Belushi for all his movies except this one.

The Blues Brother is a hilarious musical about 2 brothers who are in a band together. One of the brothers is released from jail and decides to get the old band back together. Claiming that they are on a mission from God, the 2 boys in suits go around looking for gigs. They are constantly getting themselves into trouble. The songs are hilarious, well-performed, and incredibly catchy.

reviews.review_title: Get yourself four chickens and a coke when you watch this...
reviews.content: Before Harold and Kumar went to White Castle, before Eurotrip, there was the Blues Brothers. This is one wacky movie of two brothers and their band going in search of the perfect gig, and the misadventures and plain ridiculousness they encounter along the way. Two expressionless brothers, an overly dedicated police force, one psychotic former fiancé, an American Nazi group out for revenge and an infuriated country-band and bar owner later, you get an action-packed film. Throw in some epic singers, now you have an action-packed musical.A movie with a thick taste for nonsensical destruction and deadpan delivery, Blues Brothers is a great mix of comedy and action with great vocal credit.

This classic comedy is one that has long been one that I have meant to watch. Been hearing so much about it all these years, yet it's only now I've watched it.The sad passing of Aretha Franklin of late led me to finally in memory of her to dig out this movie for a viewing. (RIP)Verdict? It's as good as it's proponents say. It's not a musical, just a grand comedy of two Blues fans who 'see the light' and are on a 'mission from God' to raise money to save their childhood orphanage.It's as crazy as that sounds.
