reviews.review_title: One of the best comedies ever, and the best "SNL" I can think of...
reviews.content: There's something funny about the actual Blues Brothers, Jake and Elwood. You don't even have to hear them say anything particularly funny to laugh at the sheer sight of the wacky duo lined up against one another, wearing the infamous clothing and sunglasses. And since their appearance on "Saturday Night Live," and then later in their milestone feature film, they have infiltrated society."The Blues Brothers" (1980) is, and will remain as far as I see it, the funniest "SNL" skit adaptation to ever hit the big screen. The problem with adapting characters from 5-minute skits on "Saturday Night Live" is the fact that they are just that -- 5-minute skits -- and are not substantial enough to merit any type of further focus. Backdrops are not needed -- all we need are quirky characters with distinguishing traits or gestures that will make us laugh."The Ladies Man," "The Coneheads," "A Night At the Roxbury," and "Superstar" are all examples of material stretched too far -- basically just skits multiplied by their original running length some 15 or so times. In fact, there are really only two or three feature length movies with "SNL" characters that are any good. I love "Saturday Night Live," but even I have to admit that some things are not meant to be turned into a movie. I'd rather see a compilation of the character's best moments on the show hit the big screen as opposed to a weak plot-driven film about them doing many unfunny things a quarter as funny as anything on the television program."The Blues Brothers" has a great plot (considering it's an "SNL" film) and a great pair of characters. Jake Blues (John Belushi) has just been released from prison, greeted by his taller (and more slender) brother Elwood (Dan Aykroyd). They visit the old Catholic home where they were raised as children by "The Penguin," and are instantly thrust into a mission to save the orphanage by raising a ton of money before it is due to close.How will they do this? Reunite their old band, of course! But it won't be easy, because in the process they get entangled in the affairs of a Neo-Nazi and a heavily armed woman (cameo by Carrie Fisher). They also get entwined in a bunch of musical sequences with blues legends such as James Brown, Aretha Franklin, and Ray Charles. (John Candy also stars in this film, and in John Hughes' masterpiece "Planes, Trains and Automobiles," he did the "mess around" to Ray Charles' song on the radio while driving an awful car.)It's all in the name of fun, of course. Oh, and in the name of God. Quoting Elwood, "We're on a mission from God." Not exactly a laugh-out-loud line of dialogue, but the more you think about it, the funnier it becomes.All my readers are probably aware of the fact that I absolutely love "Saturday Night Live" and all its actors. (Well, most of them.) Especially the older posse of actors such as Bill Murray, Chevy Chase, Dan Aykroyd, Steve Martin (frequent guest host), John Belushi, et al. They're like dear old friends and every time I see them on old reruns of the television show I get instant nostalgia. When you become a fan of "Saturday Night Live," you enter a sort of small group of friends you've never even met. You just somehow feel very close to the actors and their friends. John Landis, the film's director, was one of those close friends of Dan Aykroyd like Harold Ramis.The Blues Brothers are two of the best characters to ever come out of "Saturday Night Live." We've seen a lot of characters like Mango and Mary Katharine Gallagher lately, but the best characters are the fondest -- Wayne and Garth, The Lounge Singer, The Coneheads, The Cheeseburger Guy, The Blues Brothers. And just about any character Steve Martin plays.I can't explain why I enjoy "Saturday Night Live" so much -- is it the humor? the acting? the familiarity feel? -- but I can say that I DO love it, and I love "The Blues Brothers." Sequels can become nasty things or splendid things, and "The Blues Brothers 2000," which reunited Aykroyd and Landis (the director), was a failure. A compilation of musical sketches and a terribly recycled plot, it was a sure sign that The Blues Brothers themselves worked not only because of Elwood but also because of Jake, and "The Blues Brothers" the movie worked not because of a recycled plot but because of an original one. (And here's advice for the filmmakers: never, ever replace John Belushi with John Goodman ever, ever again.)I am sure that anyone who enjoyed "Ghostbusters" or any type "SNL"-alumni film will absolutely adore "The Blues Brothers." I mean, this is the stuff legends are made of. Jake and Elwood Blues, two of the most familiar faces of all time. How can you not laugh at this film? It's impossible. Yes, it's a bit long, and yes, you have to sit through some blues music; but they're The Blues Brothers. What else would you expect?5/5 stars.John Ulmer

reviews.review_title: Heavily dependant on the (high quality) music scenes
reviews.content: John Landis was a director that was very active in the 80s especially in the comedy and horror genre. He also made the famous "Thriller" vieoclip for Michael Jackson (almost a short movie)."The Blues brothers" is his best known film. It is about two brothers (played by John Belushi and Dan Aykroyd) that try to resurrect the band they once were playing in to raise money for the orphanage where they grew up. Most of the other band members are however married and settled and less than enthusiastic.In this respect the film resembles "Young adult" (2011, Jason Reitman) in which a former high school beauty queen thinks she can win back without difficulty her former boyfriend, also married and settled in the meantime. The difference is that "Young adult" is a drama movie, and the attempt is a complete failure. "The blues brothers" however is a comedy and ultimately the brothers succeed. After all they are "on a mission from God".The film ends with a spectacular scene of the benefit concert of the reunited Blues Brothers band. Before that the story is rather meager, consisting mainly of car chase - and music scenes.The car chase scenes are a parody and exaggerate this type of scenes seen in detective movies. This exaggeration however does not make these scenes any funnier. I am not a big fan of this type of scenes. Suggesting a lot of action, but being rather predictable and boring in reality.Of high quality are the music scenes. Could it be otherwise with appearances of James Brown, Aretha Franklin and Ray Charles? Highlight in this respect is for me the scene in which the band (because of a mix up) has a performance in a country and western bar. They quickly realize that a change of repertoire is necessary and start to sing "Stand by your man" (1975, Tammy Wynette). A rather cynical change of repertoire, because the brothers are doing everything in their might to convince their former band members to leave their wives.Over the years "The Blues Brothers" has become a cult movie. If you go to a dress up party in black and white, sunglasses and fedora hat, everybody knows who you are. Depending on your posture they take you for Jake Blues (John Belushi) or Elwood Blues (Dan Aykroyd). As always with cult movies there are attempted successions (not of the storyline (that would be a remake), but of the look, feel and mood). In this respect I would like to mention "The Comittments" (1991, Alan Parker) and, to a lesser extent, "O brother, where art thou?" (2000, Joel and Ethan Coen).

reviews.review_title: A cure for the blues, is BB, can it really have been made over 30 years ago?
reviews.content: Elwood Blues (Dan Ackroyd) is picking up his brother, Jake (John Belushi), who is getting out of prison. Their new vehicle is an old police car, which Jake initially pooh poohs, until he admits it has "nice pick up". Also, their Chicago apartment has a train going by "so often" you won't notice it. When they visit their former Catholic grade school to ask for spiritual advice, an irate nun, knowing their criminal activities, warns them not to come back until "they redeem themselves". Also, the school needs money, desperately. Not long after that, the two attend a church service where the charismatic preacher (the one and only James Brown) inspires them to get their blues band back together and make money for the Catholic school. After locating all of their former bandmates, some reluctant to re-up or having spouses who discourage them (Aretha Franklin is one), they get their first gig. Unfortunately, due to miscommunication, it is at a country bar. Thinking quickly, they launch into the Rawhide theme and Stand By Your Man. After several concerts, they get in trouble with the law and are almost caught by the angry former galfriend (Carrie Fisher) of Jake's but he charms his way out of it. With most of the Chicago police force after em, will they pay the school's debts? This film is anything BUT blue. Its a laugh fest, with a great cast. As one of the few films Belushi was able to make, it is a must see. The script is wildly funny, the scenery great, the direction first rate and the music wonderful. Don't be blue this weekend, not when you can get this film!

Great film, star studded cast, great music, and a bloody good laugh!! The cast is brilliant, Dan and John are two naturally funny guys and there are plenty of famous blues singer in it (Ray Charles, James Brown, Aretha Franklin, etc).The music is wonderful, all the classic blues songs that everyone has heard no matter what age they are. Some elements of the plot are unbelievable and so ridiculous but you just have to go with. Indeed by the end of the film the brothers had the police, the government, the Nazis, crazy lady in love with Jake, and The Good Ol' Boys!! You can't take any of it seriously, just laugh.

From writer/director John Landis (National Lampoon's Animal House, An American Werewolf in London), I remember seeing this once and thinking it was brilliant, I had to see it again to see if that was still the case. Basically 'Joliet' Jake Blues (John Belushi) has just been released from prison, and he and his brother Elwood Blues (Dan Aykroyd, also writing) return to the orphanage run by nuns where they were raised as children. They find out that the church has stopped giving support to the orphanage and that unless they can pay the $5000 tax on the property it will be sold, so they go the church for some inspiration. Jake sees the light and suggests that he and Elwood should reunite their old blues band and raise the money by selling out all seats in an arena gig. So they set off on their "mission from God" to find their fellow band members to join them, and they don't care what it takes, they won't even stop for the police or any old enemies. One by one Jake and Elwood do find the members of the band, while being chased by the cops, an army of Nazis and an enraged Mystery Woman (Carrie Fisher), and of course having a few song and dance scenes with old friends. After all are reunited, and playing a small gig under a false identity to warm up, they are ready for their big concert where they do indeed manage to sell all seats, and they play with great reaction, and manage to get away from the cops in the audience. The final scene sees Jake and Elwood speeding to the tax office with the £5000 to pay for the orphanage, and they do manage to do this before being arrested for all the damage and chaos they caused in their journey. Also starring Kathleen Freeman as Sister Mary 'The Penguin' Stigmata, James Brown as Reverend Cleophus James, Cab Calloway as Curtis, Ray Charles as Ray, Aretha Franklin as Mrs. Murphy, John Candy as Burton Mercer, Escape to Witch Mountain's Henry Gibson as Head Nazi, Steve Lawrence as Maury Sline, Charles Napier as Tucker McElroy, young Steven Spielberg as Cook County Assessor's Office Clerk, Twiggy as Chic Lady, Pee-wee's Big Adventure's Paul Reubens as Waiter, Frank Oz as Corrections Officer, Landis himself as Trooper La Fong, John Lee Hooker as Street Slim, The Fresh Prince of Bel-Air's James Avery as Man dancing outside Ray's shop and Mr. T as Guy on Street. Belushi and Aykroyd are fantastic as the criminally minded but ultimately likable brothers, the cameo appearances by legends of music and film makes for fun viewing, the plot is simple and there are a fair amount of laughable moments (including possibly unintentional), and of course the song and dance sequences, including the memorable "Everybody Needs Somebody To Love", are great fun, a most watchable musical comedy. It was number 24 on The 100 Greatest Musicals, and it was number 12 on The 50 Greatest Comedy Films. Very good!

I'm not going to spend long on this one because most of the things that I could say are obvious and have already been said (it's brilliant, great music etc.) The only thing that have to say is What An Amazing Theme Tune. I've never heard a theme tune so damn jazzy in all my life. And one more thing, there was some idiot on this site who said that "they get chased by the entire Chicago police force and don't get caught". Well Duh!! They're on a mission from God!And of course the best line in the film: -"It's 106 miles to Chicago, we've got a full tank of gas, half a packet of cigarettes, it's dark and we're wearing sunglasses. -Hit it."

All u need to know about how great this film is , is to look at its cast ,John Belushi,, Dan Aykroyd, John Candy , Carrie Fisher, James Brown , Aretha Franklyn, Twiggy, Cab Calloway, Ray Charles,and the other one.Yes its possibly dated, times have changed infact the Nazi scenes remind me of a happier time when Nazis where universally despised but lets not get too political.its a happy feel good movie with not possibly but defiantly the best soundtrack ever of any movie. the sound track alone is worth a 10Ive not even touched on the producer , John Landis who to me is one of the finest producers of the 80s. with such credits as the Michael Jackson thriller video and American Werewolf in London ( which has possibly the best on screen werewolf transformation sequences in movie history) you just know your in for a great 2 hours and 13 mins ride.A cult classic & deservedly so.

reviews.review_title: One of the most over-rated movies
reviews.content: Were it not for the pathetic provincialism of movie-goers from Chicago, this awful movie would rate about a 3 or 4 at most. The premise is rather lame, especially given that Belushi and Aykroyd are terrible singers--two white guys calling themselves "the Blues Brothers" is an insult to any real blues singers! The movie's plot is slap-dash, seemingly thrown together to exploit a throw-away sketch from SNL. This movie started the long trend of bad movies based on throw-away sketches from SNL. I realize it is meant as a live-action cartoon, but so many seams are left showing that suspending one's disbelief becomes a chore. Many people love this film because they can't watch it objectively. They see only their favorite comic actors from the past. It's like that Top 40 hit you loved from high school that just embarrasses you now when you hear it. I saw it when it first came out, and it was over-hyped then and hasn't aged well at all. Most professional movie critics see _The Blues Brothers_ for what it is: a mediocre star vehicle that crashes like an old Chicago police car flying out of lower Wacker Drive.

reviews.review_title: Rarely Funny, And Very Little Blues Music. This Is A Dissspointing And Mindless Film Folks.
reviews.content: Very dissapointed. I had never watched it before, and was anticipating the great classic comedy that I had always heard that it was supposed to be. But frankly, it was rarely funny. Not sure if it's because it's beyond its expiry date, or whether maybe it was never all that funny. But that was not even the most dissapointing thing. The real issue I had with it, was that their was very little Blues music in it. In fact, theirs very little music at all. And that was the main reason I wanted to watch it. Now, if you love the sight of literally dozens and dozens of police cars being smashed up then by all means watch the movie. As far as the Belushi/Ackroyd cool factor, it lasts about twenty minutes around the start of the film. Then it fades. This is pretty mindless stuff folks.

I loved this. Really good. If you feel like laughing this is it. From singing to dancing. This movie kept me in. I managed to catch it before leaving Netflix. And, couldn't help but laugh at some of the stuff they did in the movie.

reviews.review_title: The Blues Brothers = The Best Musical Comedy Ever Made!
reviews.content: I just love everything about this movie, from the comedy of John Belushi and Dan Aykroyd (the straight man's straight man), to the fabulous music, the stellar cameos, and most especially the car chases. I just love seeing all those police cars getting smashed up. BTW, did you know that TBB held the world record for the most cars destroyed in one film until it was surpassed by its own sequel? (I got that from Wikipedia, which has great articles on both the movie and the band.) My favorite scenes are early in the movie. The first is the scene with Sister Mary Stigmata, aka "The Penguin", where she's whacking them for using foul language. The other is the scene where the brothers find themselves stuck in a line of cars stopped on the road. When the ask a passing policeman what's going on, and find out it's a march of "the f#&%ing Nazis", Jake utters my favorite line in the movie, "I HATE Illinois Nazis", and they charge the Bluesmobile straight towards those f#&%ing Nazi bastards and force them to jump off the bridge. Every time I watch that scene, I shout, "YES! Illinois Nazis, IN THE WATER!!". Now, I'm a tolerant Christian man, and I belong to a large multicultural church, and they teach "hate the sin, not the sinner", but I feel EXACTLY the way the Blues Brothers do about Nazis of all stripes. This movie really has it all! I could go on and on about this musical farce, but space is limited, so I'll just say YOU MUST SEE AND BUY THIS MOVIE!!

reviews.review_title: "Saturday Night Live" finds success on the big screen
reviews.content: This 1980 Universal release was the first film to be based upon characters and sketches from the hit TV series "Saturday Night Live." John Belushi and Dan Aykroyd reprise their TV roles as Jake and Elwood Blues, two brothers who attempt to raise money to save their childhood orphanage by reuniting their old band members and having a concert. A lot of comedic destruction happens along the way. Several big stars have cameos throughout the film. One of the best of the film incarcerations of "Saturday Night Live" sketches.

reviews.review_title: Makes you grin and tap your foot all through the film!
reviews.content: More fantastic songs from fantastic singers than you can shake a stick at!!

It's movies like this why the 80's are my favorite decade of film, pure magic. John Belushi and Dan Akroyd play the perfect pair of brothers as they go on a true epic of a journey to save their orphanage. They cross the cops, a rugged country band, and yes of course, Nazis. We get kick ass car chases, a jamming soundtrack, clever cameos, and of course unforgettable one liners. This movie has it all.The music numbers in this movie are a lot of fun, and seeing the band play together are some of the best bits in the film.The overall story of the film is simple but engaging. It's always fun, never takes itself seriously, and always delivers something fresh.You really root for Elwood and Joliet Jake as they make their way on their mission from God. An absolute blast. This movie is an essential watch for people who love blues/jazz music, comedies, or 80's movies in general.

reviews.review_title: A movie about two men who are on a mission from God.
reviews.content: This movie is an obsolute masterpiece.  John Landis directed this classic in what turned out to be one of the funnest movies of all time. What is so incredible is how Landis got all these major actors and actresses to work together and create a movie like this. Belushi and Aykroyd(Jake and Elwood) are on a mission from God in trying to save a church that owes $5000 in property taxes. Along their "mission" they encounter every obstacle known to man and overcome them all.  The musical performances are outstanding and the line-up of singers makes the movie into a musical concert.  It delivers over 2 hours in non-stop action and laughs and must be on everyone's "must see" list.  You can literally watch this movie hundreds of times and never get bored. This is classic Belushi and to watch him perform his magic on the screen is enough to make you watch this one over and over. Ray Charles, James Brown, Aretha Franklin, Cab Calloway, Carrie Fisher, and the rest of the Blues Brother Band are just to the beginning to a wonderful, cleverly done movie. This is a must-own movie!

This is my all time favourite film, it's got an ace soundtrack,top actors and a great storyline.The comedy elements are continual throughout the entire film and all the characters are spot on. The relentless vision of the main characters to round up and reform the band in order to try and save their orphanage from closure is superbly portrayed. Also I am astounded that so many great actors and talented musicians were brought together to be part of this film, it's like a time warp of blues/soul history which captures so much of life at that time,especially the market blues festival scene with John Lee Hooker singing in the street. Not a lot more to be said about it really, Highly recommended. 10/10.

I can think of no other movie that achieves the hypnotic blend that Blues Brothers pulls off. Much of the music in this film couldn't have been further from the popular radar than it was in 1980, and yet the movie made you love it. The delivery of the comedy is a snapshot of the time. Belushi and Aykroyd were at the top of what was hip, funny and cool at that time, but played characters that were far from trendy. For better or worse, comedy is no longer delivered as it was here. It delights my senses musically, visually and comedically.Ray Charles with a pistol. Parishioners doing leaping back flips, 20 feet in the air. A flashmob song and dance in a soul food joint. A traffic menace warranting the involvement of ALL cop cars in Chicago. Ridiculous. Ridiculously awesome.So many classic lines, and belly laughs that you don't normally get in a second viewing, let alone a 50th viewing.

Based on some sketches from "Saturday Night Live" TV show. Brothers Jake (John Belushi) and Elwood (Dan Aykroyd) find out the orphanage they grew up in is being closed because they can't afford the rent increase. They decide to get the blues band they used to be part of to get together and raise money. The movie is basically a musical comedy of them getting the band together and trying to raise money. Along the way we get some GREAT songs sung by blues artists. All the songs are wonderful and the dance numbers are full or color and energy. My favorite has to be Aretha Franklin belting out "Think". I like it a lot and recommend it but I don't love it. At 133 minutes it's a bit too long and there are WAY too many car chases and crashes. It got so over the top me and my partner started giggling by the end! Still it's worth seeing. Not a big hit when it came out but it's now considered a comedy classic!

Based on the classic SNL skit of the awesome duo John Belushi and Dan Akroyd they finally get there shot on the big screen! After getting out of Jail Jake reunites the band to save their hometown!But they have lots of people who want them dead. The cops, Some crazy bitch who tries to kill them at every turn, and even Nazis! That's right Nazis!What really was the highlight was not the Epic chase scene at the end or the car falling from the sky no it was the catchy, energetic and fast paced music and dance scenes! Hell, even I felt like dancing a bit <3Not to mention you got cameos by Aeretha Franklin, Ray Charles, Cab Calloway, and Carrie Fishers gad freakin' zooks!That all said this is one hell of an enjoyable movie from start to finish I definitely recommend you watch this with your friends.PERFECT 10/10Oh and by the way I could have SWORN I saw these guys in Earthbound. I think they were called the runaway 5 and I tell ya the blues bros. were Definitely in there.Heck I think they had a brief appearance in Smash Bros. Melee's intro.

reviews.review_title: One of the best films ever
reviews.content: Nuff said. Its great. I need to make a longer review.

reviews.review_title: I forgot how much fun movies can be
reviews.content: It's been a couple of years since I've enjoyed comedy this much. This days, comedies are usually not funny at all or just plain disgusting, or both (actors may have a lot of fun filming them, but someone should really check whether the audience will enjoy them too).The plot of "The Blues Brothers" is pretty straightforward, and while the acting could've been a bit better (they are all so stiff) it kinda fits perfectly with the movie's theme. Everything was so over the top so nothing seemed to be an excess (except maybe Carrie Fisher).To conclude, this is a great movie and I'll probably watch it again sometime soon.

Rollicking good film with Belushi and Aykroyd donning soulful look as Jake and Elwood Blues, two improbable bandleaders. Great music. Superb cameos from James Brown, Ray Charles, Aretha Franklin and of course, Cab Calloway. The film without the music is mess, so thank God for that music!

reviews.review_title: A hugely influential film of its decade
reviews.content: Having never seen Saturday Night Live before I watched this film, it just happened to come across the pond with some direction, comedy and of course a great visual encyclopaedia of Rhythm and Blues music. This film alone sparked my interest in black music, particularly the Blues.Jake and Elwood Blues are on a mission from God to raise funds for their former orphanage with some great results. They have to reassemble their band and the end result is spectacular with the music, it's humour and the car chases. Dotted with music legends such as John Lee Hooker, Ray Charles and Aretha Franklin to name but a few is a film watch, own and follow.

This has got to be the movie I've seen most often, maybe upward of a hundred times! (Of course, this is partly because my fifteen year old grandson watches it about once a week, but what the hell, I told him about it).I hesitate to say it's a good movie. It isn't carefully plotted, and it doesn't have very subtle acting in it. But if it isn't good, it somehow manages to get around this by being, very simply, GREAT. Of course, it's largely the music that does it. Imagine seeing and hearing Aretha Franklin, Ray Charles, John Lee Hooker and James Brown in the space of about two hours, not to mention the Blues Brothers' own fantastic R & B sound! And there's Cab Calloway's Minnie the Moocher....But maybe even more than the music, it's the tone of the whole thing. How rare, how moving to see R & B and soul and the blues openly worshipped (even if a bit wackily)! How satisfying to see country music, which has caused me so much aesthetic agony, sent up so hilariously! That scene in the country and western bar, where the Brothers sing Rawhide has got to be one of the most delicious bits of satire I've ever seen! And imagine Twiggy being stood up by an evil smelling bluesman. What a fantasy for all us blues-loving losers! Someone should give John Landis about a dozen lifetime awards for making this fantastic movie. Then maybe other directors will start making good movies about musicians, like this one and 'Round Midnight

This is a great movie, extremely funny, good music, amazingly filmed and directed, great cast...it's just one of my favorites. The opening half hour or so and the last half hour are the best parts in my opinion. Fantastically over-the-top car crashes that will blow your mind!  In fact the whole movie is incredibly over the top.  This film is filled with unbelievable shots and camera-angles...John Landis really came up with some creative stuff.  The opening shots of the industrial wasteland of Joliet are great stuff.  See this film, you won't be disappointed!!

What is all this muck about blues? You have two fat guys driving around the place, being chased by hundreds of police cars- and they can't even catch them. Then they go to some bars and play  blues music, one of the worst forms of music along with country. This film has a huge cult following. But it is boring and lasts TWO AND A HALF HOURS for charley's sake! Barely a giggle in sight. 3/10

how much better can a film be? Ray Charles, John Belushi, Dan Aykroyd, Aretha Franklin, James Brown, John Candy, Tom Malone, Cab Calloway- need i name more? Absolutely amazing, the plot, the cast, the soundtrack- EVERYTHING! Best car chase ever! Their music, humour and action leaves a now cult classic which is the blues brothers, never to be missed.Along side the film itself is the most fantastic soundtrack to accompany the love of the film. Even their rendition of Stand by your Man!They are on a mission from God and nothing or no one will stop them- not even the Illinois Nazi Party, Carrie Fisher or the police. Recommend it to everyone.

reviews.review_title: Fantastic mixture of Blues, great one liners and over the top car chases.
reviews.content: To deride the movie as 'silly' is to miss the point - it's a backdrop to great old blues/rnb/soul music. It's a superb movie to cheer you up, and can be watched repeatedly.No, it's not perfect, and it does require that you like the music to derive real enjoyment, but just sit down and relax, drink in the music, crack a smile at the one liners and while away a couple of happy hours.8/10 in case something better comes along.

reviews.review_title: Changed my whole personality in my high school years.
reviews.content: The first time I ever saw "The Blues Brothers" was in 1992.  It appeared on TBS, edited of course.  I wasn't even watching it... I just had the TV on while I was doing some work on my computer.Then... the mall scene.The stunts... the sounds... the people diving for cover... the one-liners... and the music, oh the MUSIC!  I had to turn around and watch, as it even caught my attention with my back turned.  After watching for 5 minutes, I turned it off and left.  Not because I didn't like it, mind you... but because I could see that the "bad words" had been dubbed over (obviously), and it ticked me off that they did this to a movie that was so entertaining to me.  So, I turned it off, jumped in my car, and shot over to Blockbuster and rented it.I watched it twice when I got home.  Heh... I'd NEVER done that before.  Not since I was a kid, anyway.  Never actually stopped a movie when the credits came on, rewound it, and then watched it AGAIN.  OH, but I loved it! Everything about it... the attitudes, the singing, the car chases, the clothes... the fedoras... the sunglasses.If you haven't seen this movie, please watch it.  I'm proud to say that "The Blues Brothers" is known as the first "big-budget" movie in history.  If you don't believe me, watch what happens in the movie when they finally get to Chicago.Listen... I just-- can't say enough about this movie.  I own a framed original movie poster from 1980.  I've been to the House of Blues in Chicago... I bought a Black fedora and Wayfarer Ray-bans-- I know-- I know: geeky, perhaps.  But that's HOW STINKIN' GOOD this movie was!!  It MAKES you wanna be geeky and like them!  Well... it makes ME, anyway.  I don't know... maybe I'm just a geek, and you're all laughing at me right now.  But it STILL wouldn't change the fact that "The Blues Brothers" is ONE GREAT MOVIE!!--dog-gonnit...

reviews.review_title: John Belishi: The Orson Welles of comedy if he were still alive Moses and Aaron in the Ten Commandments would be Belushi and Ackroyd
reviews.content: John Belishi: The Orson Welles of comedy if he were still alive Moses and Aaron in the Ten Commandments would be Belushi and Ackroyd. WHAT an AWESOME pair these two guys were . . . the LAST COMEDY TEAM (Laural and Hardy; Abbott and Costello; Burns and Allen; The Marx Brothers; The Three Stooges; Dan Ackroyd and John Belushi) They fit right in . . . thank God for these guys. . . . right: the movie . . . the BEST BLUES BROTHERS MOVIE ABOUT BLUES MUSIC an QUEST and a mission movie ever made . . . and the car crashes Superb i don't think we can really ever appreciate the awesomeness of the blues brothers . . .I mean Halloween, John Carpenter's The Thing, Dawn of the Dead, Night of the Living Dead, Texas Chainsaw Massacre, Evil Dead, Nightmare on Elm Street, Jaws, ET, Psycho, The Blues Brothers, Forrestr Gump, Star Wars III, IV, V, VI, Rocky 1,2,3,4,5, The Karate Kid 1, 2, 3, Poltergeist, Alien, Aliens, Its a Wonderful Life, The Graduate, The Terminator, American Werewolf in London, Coming to America, The Road Warrior, 48 hrs., Sid and Nancy, stand By Me, Kramer Vs. Kramer, Tootsie, Radio Days, Take the Money and Run, Arthur, The Breakfast Club, Ferris Buehler's Day Off, Planes, Trains and Automobiles, Ghostbusters i and ii, The Godfather i and ii, Deliverance, Star Trek II, IV, III, Animal House, The World According to Garp, Summer of '42 ) THESE MOVIES . . . man, The Blues Brothers, we can't really appreciate them: they're so damn good. THE BLUES BROTHERS: its a classic that I carry in my memory wherever I am. John Candy: hey guys; we're in a truck. or the scene where everyone asks: where's Jake and we see the guy smoking a pipe on stage . . . implying Jake or John's getting high somewhere. God, i miss John Belushi . . . Belushi's name is up there with those movies i mentioned. God, I miss Belushi. he was hilarious and sad at the same time. Judy, keep loving John--i read Samarui Widow and man, those kids at the grave . . . speaking for them: I'm sorry for your loss, God bless you. THE BLUES BROTHERS. If anyone reading this is feeling down. Watch The Blues Brothers, you'll carry it with you. its beyond a 10 its a classic.

reviews.review_title: An hilarious movie! I loved it!
reviews.content: The story of the Blues Brothers is the classic tale of the underdog rising above their former self and helping those that need their help. This movie takes this form of storytelling and strings a crazy, comedic adventure through it. The Blues Brothers, Elwood Blues (Aykroyd) and and Jake Blues (Belushi) are two unlikely heroes that travel around searching for their lost band-mates so they can pull off one more gig to raise money to save the orphanage where they grew up. Along the way they encounter trouble, sometimes intentional and sometimes not. It just seems to find them. Aykroyd and Belushi are an hilarious and wonderful pair as they spout their lines back and forth. Their physical comedy is even better. The film as a whole nails physical comedy on the head with its car chase scenes especially. This movie has a bit of a script issue as one can forget what exactly the purpose of the Blues Brother's intentions all along are. While watching I forgot about the Orphanage as the movie had completely centered around the band and the Blues Brother's shenanigans. All accounted for, I'd rate this movie a 8 out of 10. It's an amazing comedy and timeless. Aykroyd and Belushi are lovable idiots as the Blues Brothers.

reviews.review_title: One of the best musicals (if you can say musical;))
reviews.content: Watching it and love it. One of my most watched movies.

reviews.review_title: Timeless classic, awesome music and an awesome cast... plus the best car chases ever!
reviews.content: The Blues Brothers is one of the best movies I have ever seen. With so many music legends in here and Belushi and Aykroyd are brilliant. When they perform in the film it is classic stuff. You can watch this film over and over again just to listen to the music. To listen to James Brown, Ray Charles, Aretha Franklin, Cab Calloway and the Blues Brothers. The songs are all brilliant. And the ending that must have been one almighty wage demand. It must have cost a lot of money to destroy all the glass, cars and just everything. Then add that to the cameos from huge stars and the actual cast in full. But one of if not the best bit is the car chase. All those cars piling up the chase in the mall, through Chicago and all the cars getting destroyed. Falling from a great height and creating a huge hole in the road, crashing into trucks, flying into lakes it has everything. Humour, action, fabulous music, what more do you need in a movie. At two and a half hours might test the patience of some people but it was totally worth it. One of my favourites, one for the ages. Great writing by Dan Aykroyd and John Landis and great directing by Landis. And another great way to remember Cab Calloway, Ray Charles but mainly John Belushi.
I absolutely love this film. It's got too humour, amazing music, some of the biggest R&B stars of the time and ridiculous over-the-top action. What's not to love?

reviews.review_title: ONE of the prefect comedies of the last three decades
reviews.content: You read that right.     There's no point in going over the plot. If you're reading this review, you already know the movie most likely. Besides being riotously funny, the characters from "The Penguin" (the late great comic actress Kathleen Freeman) to Jake's homicidal ex-girlfriend (Carrie Fisher in a particularly inspired role. I even like the name of her hair salon "The Curl Up And Die") are beautifully realized. There is not a lame second in this opus. And the MUSIC! WOW!!!   Damn the plotholes and full speed ahead. This film, along with "The Producers," "Stripes," "Animal House" and maybe "Caddyshack," this is one of the most flawlessly realized gut-busting comedies of all time. Add to this the amazing line-up of musical talent from John Lee Hooker, to Ray Charles to the mighty Cab Calloway to the Queen Of Soul Aretha Franklin doing another fabulous rendition of "Think," this is a tribute to R&B and soul the true American music as well as a perfectly thought out exercise in funny!   What makes it all the more remarkable is that it holds up so well. I still have favorite moments I look forward to when watching this film and some are just as simple as the "Cheese Whiz" toss to the old man in the divy hotel alongside the El to the C&W waitress proudly telling our heroes that "We have ALL kinds of music. We have country AND western."    I just wish I could rattle off those long lines with all sorts of references like the great Dan Ackroyd. I also consider myself privileged to have MET Belushi and the late Gilda Radner (who, sadly, has not had a single good film in her repertoire. She deserved better) There's something I can share with my grandkids.    And I agree with Elwood. I too hate Illinois Nazis - unless they are going over a cliff.    If you haven't seen this movie, BUY IT and you won't regret it....unless you don't like great music and funny comedies...then maybe you ARE an Illinois Nazi, in which case....

This is (in my opinion) the best movie that Dan Aykroyd and John Belushi ever starred in! I remembered watching this as a kid and dressing up with my grandpa in my black suit, hat and sunglasses. I even wrote my name as well as "Jake" and "Elwood" on my fingers for fun! I loved it, then, now, forever!

reviews.review_title: A goofy musical comedy that will leave you with a smile on the face and a warmth in your heart
reviews.content:
Blues Brothers... now why does that name sound familiar? Some might remember them from a recurring musical sketch on NBC variety series "Saturday Night Live", but growing up in Europe - I was never exposed to those sketches. I had to dig deeper and finally discovered that I heard of them from a highly unlikely source - Nickelodeon. Yes, during the mid-2000s, they ran a sitcom called "Drake & Josh" that featured an episode called "Blues Brothers" that not only ended with them creating a tribute to the Blues Brothers by performing a rendition of "Soul Man" (the song was not featured in the film), but, BUT, also featured a short scene from the movie! Sounds crazy, I know, and this rabbit hole and the revelation took me on a path of nostalgia as it was one of my favorite sitcoms when growing up.
The one thing that really caught my eye was the way the budget was used. If I had the time, I'd count how many cars they crashed in this film, how much glass was shattered, and how many costumes were used for both the police department and the soldier outfits. Speaking of that, what seemed like a tame comedy got out of hand with ridiculousness as the movie progressed. I didn't mind it as it fed off the charm of our two protagonists and their almost oblivious reactions to the whole ordeal going around them gave that ridiculous chaos a life on its own.
And let's not forget the memorable stars this movie featured - John Belushi and Dan Aykroyd did a good job playing Jake and Elwood respectably, Carrie freaking Fisher (RIP) as the mysterious woman, who turned out to be a former love interest of Jake, was probably the most random one but hey, if you have a chance to sign big names like that, I'd go for it too, even Aretha Franklin... sorry... THE ARETHA FRANKLIN was featured as the café owner and she even performed! I might be geeking out since I'm a fan of her but that scene sure made my jaw drop and my heart might have skipped a few beats... and so did RAY CHARLES! "Twist it" was a really good song and the whole music was filled with good and fun musical acts, which is probably my favorite part of the film, along with the charisma and comedic presence of the Blues duo.Overall, I really enjoyed this movie. It might not be a spectacular piece of work cinematography-wise and the plot is a bit wacky for my taste, but hey, it made me feel good, and seeing as I am still stuck in quarantine, I just miss concerts even more now. Just one show like that could recharge me again.

The blues brothers is a silly film in every sense of that word,it is full of interesting and funny characters,cheesy dialogue and it has a bunch of famous musicians and singers in it,i will also not methering how absurd all of that sounds ,this film was a joy to witness and watch,i know that this film is to long even for me with its plot and subject and they could removed good 40 minutes of it since it started to drag a bit,but that didnt changed my opinion of rest of film,blues brothers has a lot of great songs in it,in which one singers did a good job in acting,dan and james were awesome together and fisher was very memorable in very little screentime,blues brothers is fun 80s comedy

The Blues Brohers, what can i say... it's a comedy. an action movie maybe even a parody. The plot is (NO Spoilers) Jake Blues, a man released from a correctional center, meets up with his brother Elwood. The blues brothers are a band and they have to get the band back together to raise $5,000 for their catholic home. What makes this movie so great is the humor, there's things people do for no reason, their chased by everyone, and by the middle of the movie. You believe this is a normal day for the two. I only have one problem with the movie, it does tend to feel a little longer than it is, but the comedy and the music make up for it. I give this movie a 3 & 1/2 stars out of four. A great movie everybody should check out. (Well, at least wait for your kid to be 14 years of age)

reviews.review_title: A Variety Show in Form of a Movie !
reviews.content: The plot is about 2 guys who are on a mission to collect certain sum of money to rescue the Catholic home by reuniting their old music band. This can be a good plot for a buddy-comedy, road movie, musical, or action. Actually the movie is all of these genres together. Well.. it has part of every one of them to be precise!It could have been some mix in the name of farce. But instead, it was mishmash done farcically. For instance, the 2 leads don't have an irony between them; being more like the same person divided in 2. They both made enemies so easily along the way. Some of the songs, if not all, got nothing to do with the events, so they were against the pace's flow. And the movie ends up as kind of dull comedy or anarchic musical.Further, the massive, very showy, climactic action sequence is too good to be true, yet stands alone, like a huge ending for another movie. It catches up with the boom of the car's long chases of that period, post-Smokey and the Bandit (1977). Though, the movie isn't an action also, it just utilizes elements of it.It goes like this: Comic Scene + Song + Action Scene, then the same of that, again and again, being about nice elements played repeatedly and absurdly. So, eventually, it's just a show, a cinematic variety show. It even reminded me of Pepe (1960), another variety show in form of a movie, with entertaining episodes and thin plot. And despite the fact that it's nearly disassembled, it managed to provide fun.Director (John Landis) enjoyed showing us how to play a slight script with craze, using comedians, iconic singers, and big cadres to hide any defects in it. The (John Belushi) radiation is highly dangerous; he can own the screen by doing nothing. Some small touches and gags were memorable. I loved the first sequence where (Joliet) is going out of the jail in holy moment-like, (Belushi) and (Aykroyd) come out of the hotel's debris dusting down their suits indifferently, the end's blowing up and clever chases. Let alone singing the finale song by all the movie's great singers in one last montage. And the idea of (Carrie Fisher) as obscure mad sniper who hunts the 2 leads with machine guns, bombs, and rockets was super funny.As for the songs, (Theme From Rawhide) and (Minnie The Moocher) were the most entertaining episodes; like paying 2 separated homage during the "show" to the old TV, and the old Jazz too. I don't think that (Joliet) and (Elwood) song at the end was that impressive to earn all of that success, but maybe it was in the way they performed it, so this movie itself; it proved how a movie can make a large bubble out of small gum.By the way, I thought that the movie could have had more audience if it wasn't R-rated. And it's R for the slightest reasons ever, namely it could have been better without couple of sexual shots and swearing words. So it sounded like PG-13 movie that got the wrong R sprinkle!In another dimension, that could've flopped hard. It happened already when they repeated the same formula later in Blues Brothers 2000 (1998) without (Belushi), the sudden impact, and in lower action too (How Dare They?!). Simply, they disrobed it from what hides its own imperfections.Anyway, for a last verdict, The Blues Brothers (1980) is like (Carrie Fisher)'s character in it; childish, explosive, jest.

Great songs, great cast, great cameos. This movie has everything.Musicals usually have 2 major flaws, the music dates and the songs always seem forced. This is not true in the Blues Brothers, as the songs still sound fantastic 25 years on and the songs naturally fit into the story and are part of the plot rather than set-pieces. The film is hilariously funny and there is a natural chemistry between John Belushi and Dan Aykroyd that makes their roles as near perfect as possible.The car chase and subsequent crashes are among the most impressive that I can remember and the supporting cast offer up some great songs, most notably in my opinion Ray Charles.I would include this in my top 10 films ever, and as someone who normally hates musicals with a vengeance, that says a lot.

Embarrassingly never watched this to now, as I'd heard it was a musical.O M GYou want musical?? This easily makes my top 3 films of all time and is my number one recommended to friends and family, as anyone with a hint of taste will appreciate this masterpiece.The special effects are so bad and the car chases so over the top, that this was truly hilarious and easy viewing from the beginning to end.

reviews.review_title: Fun Comedy The Reached Cult Status
reviews.content: There's never a normal day for Jake and Elwood Blues (John Belushi and Dan Aykroyd), but "The Blues Brothers" is film that has never been told before and that a lot of the ideas must have had a lot of second guessing from the people behind the scenes to determine if this film is going to work out. Both Belushi and Aykroyd made these iconic characters famous from their days on "Saturday Night Live" and now they have managed to make the big time to the silver screen of Hollywood. What makes this movie so unique we get an origin story of the brothers as it was revealed that they were raised in a very strict orphanage in the West Side of Chicago and by virtue of osmosis, they learned the blues and from the opening scenes, the brothers reunited after Jake was released from jail at a Joliet pen.The story is quite simple in its delivery. We see Jake and Elwood pay a visit to their old orphanage only to discover that the place needs $5000 to pay off back taxes.or else the orphanage will be shut down for good. This leads the brothers to reunite the band for a one night show to help raise the money to save the orphanage. The Blues Brothers travel around the mostly darker regions of Chicago like a Van Buren flophouse, Maxwell Street and Wacker Drive. They make pit-stops at a Soul Food Diner owned by Aretha Franklin, a music store owned by Ray Charles and a Baptist Church run by James Brown.Along the way, the brotherly duo manage to anger off a lot of people which includes a country/Western group, the Chicago PD and a group of Nazis who were in the middle of a demonstration. What this movie succeeds is that it successfully manages to recapture news events from the time period and incorporate it into the film. So while the cops, the country band the Nazis are after them, there is music playing in the background which some nice energy flowing into the story to add excitement to the chase scenes.With the plethora of musical talents added in the cast The Queen of Soul Aretha Franklin was the one who had the best scenes as the owner of a restaurant serving classic Soul Food. Cab Calloway though catching on in age is still as slick as her his, strutting in style with his exotic suits reliving his days when her performed Minnie the Moocher. There are quite some entertaining moments of them performing like when they were at a country bar and were surrounded by wire mesh so that they don't get doused with beer bottle while they get booed off stage.When it comes down to it, the whole film itself is one big epic chase. Even going so far as Jake and Elwood take control of a used police car that zooms through suspended bridges almost like it has a mind of its own. The movie takes a real liberation in the uses of the location. There is no safe zones when the Blues Brothers are in pursuit. They can be seen everywhere from train tracks to overpasses through subway tunnels and even through the Daley Center. The 12 car crash pileup can easily be regarded as one of the most impressive displays of stunt coordination.But underneath all the car wreckage and the millions of dollars in property damage, this film works on all levels. Director John Landis who seems to love to take risks succeeded in making movie magic while paying off all dividends for all the damage he's done to the city and the cars. Performance wise Belushi and Aykroyd were spectacular in their respected roles as self-destructive laid-back cynics who carry their class with suave charisma and style that fits the settings of the movie. This film is filled with crazy stunts, cool music and plenty of car wreckage for a wonderful night out.

What happens when you combine hilarious comedy, great music, wild vehicular stunts/crashes, and an all-star cast? It means that the fabulous Blues Brothers are in action! Written by Dan Aykroyd & John Landis, and directed by the latter, "The Blues Brothers" was a successful attempt at transferring a Saturday Night Live skit into a theatrical motion picture. The plot of this extraordinarily funny movie, with many memorable lines, involves brothers Elwood Blues (Aykroyd) and Joliet Jake Blues (John Belushi), who just keep on running afoul of the law as they reassemble the members of their rhythm & blues band in order to earn some decent money. (If you haven't yet seen "The Blues Brothers", DON'T read the rest of this commentary!)Here are my favorite highlights from this classic action musical comedy. Jake and Elwood are hilarious as they keep swearing at the nun (Kathleen Freeman) and receive a good share of smacks. The action-packed police car chase inside the shopping mall is equally hilarious. Aretha Franklin as the soul food café owner gets a chance to show some spunk in this film (prior to her much-too-long feature number "Think"). As the police & the Good Ole Boys chase the Blues Brothers away from the Palace Hotel, the lead singer/driver for the Boys (Charles Napier) realizes that Elwood secretly epoxied the gas pedal on the Boys' vehicle, so the Good Ole Boys unintentionally "go for a swim". While hordes and hordes of police officers, soldiers, and S.W.A.T. teams pursue the Blues Brothers (so overwhelming it's ridiculously funny), Elwood and Jake quietly hang out inside an elevator listening to a laughable Muzak version of "The Girl from Ipanema". Ray Charles (owner of Ray's Music Exchange) and the Blues Brothers Band do a fine performance of "Shake Your Tailfeather". At Bob's Country Bunker ("Chicken wire?"), the Blues Brothers Band applies some quick thinking to satisfy the restless patrons ("That ain't no Hank Williams song!") and offers a nice rendition of "Stand by Your Man". At the Palace Hotel Ballroom, Curtis (Cab Calloway, aka "Mr. Hi-De-Hi-De-Ho") performs a swinging "Minnie the Moocher", and the Blues Brothers do my favorite version of "Sweet Home Chicago". And finally, at the Triple Rock Baptist Church, the Reverend Cleophus James (James Brown) leads the congregation in a lively, unrealistically boisterous song titled "That Old Landmark".That's about all I can write about "The Blues Brothers"; so spectacular and enjoyable is this musical comedy from 1980. All of the actors, stunt people, and crew did a hell of a fine job with all their hard work.

John Landis and Dan Akroyd have created a milestone of comedy and music. The plot is simple and yet so intriguing, two lowlifes desperately trying to save an orphanage on the order of a sadistic nun.  The way in which the Blues Brothers manage to offend just about everyone in chicagoi is half the fun of this movie, whilst the superbly chosen soundtrack provides the rest. The gags, are fantastic, ranging from quick one liners to brilliantly well handled visuals.  John Landis' style and camera control is impeccable and blends perfectly wiht the mood of the film.  The finale scene is also a groundbreaking feet in combining unbelievable action with insanely clever comedy.  The way in which all the actors and actresses don't take it too seriously adds to the light heartedness of the piece and still makes me smile every time I see it.  A classic comedy movie with some of the best use of soundtrack I've ever seen (or heard).  People working on the blues Brothers; well done.

I was 13 years old when I first saw 'The Blues Brothers', and ever since that chilly December day in 2002, I've been hooked.This clever, madcap comedy stars the late John Belushi as Jake Blues and Dan Aykroyd as Elwood, two men who provide the vocals and harmonica for their powerhouse blues band, the Blues Brothers. After getting out of prison for armed robbery, Jake reunites with his brother Elwood and they head back to whence they were brought up, an orphanage that is about to have its doors closed unless the money needed to save it can be scrounged up. Henceforth, the 'Mission from God' was born.There is no shortage of greatness in this movie. That includes cameos, the script, the music itself and the acting. Add in a few outrageous car chases, some bitterly ticked-off Nazis and more cameos by Blues greats than you can count, and you'll really have your tail feathers shaking'. Belushi and Aykroyd can certainly carry a tune in a basket and there is no doubt that they are talented, and you have to give them credit: they delivered a fire-powered performance that I think could've been Grammy-worthy (but that's just me personally). Every number they cover is a toe-tapping, hum-worthy tune, and the albums they've put out (Made in America and Briefcase Full of Blues) are just as catchy and soulful as the movie soundtrack itself.The individual personalities of Jake and Elwood are a pleasure to follow along with throughout the film, and each band member offers at least one great, laugh-worthy line that you can't help but quote every now and again. The smart appearances by Ray Charles, Aretha Franklin and Cab Calloway also generate a lovely feeling of bluesy nostalgia and a reminiscence of the good ole days when music was actually high-quality. While it is really a shame that Belushi (who happens to be my favorite comedian) passed away two years after this film was released, there is no doubt that his memory will be fondly upheld in what is unarguably his best work.The most famous of all the quotes is the classic 'We're On A Mission From God'. Trust me, whatever the mission our suit-laden heroes were in, it was definitely fulfilled.My grade: A+, 10/10
