Ask most people what the greatest musical of all time is, and they will tell you some piece of garbage like The Sound Of Music or Mary Poppins. There are two possibilities in such an event: they're either not real musicians, or they've just never seen The Blues Brothers!The Blues Brothers is the musical of the musician. No other film gets so close to the truth of what life in the business is like for an actual musician, and no other captures the essence of what real music forms, the Blues especially, are about. Music is not about a bunch of gutless trendies following whatever the PR at Sony tells them to follow, it is about the creative dreams of ordinary men and women, just like the people listening or viewing. The scene outside the Soul Food Cafe is a perfect representation of this: an improptu band performance outside the cafe, attended by the average Joes that they made the music for.Of course, there is still a demonstration of the corruption and stagnation that has become inherent in the music industry, but rather than flaunting it as just something we have to accept, this film shows that with enough determination and work, it can be overcome. One day, I hope to get everyone who's been raised on the garbage they play on the radio these days and stick them in a hall, then play Minnie The Moocher at them. I'm sure the shock of hearing real music with a dozen musicians playing a tight, intricate rhythm in two different speeds will shatter the ease with which they can listen to repetitive noise. As a musician heavily influenced by everyone from The Blues Brothers to Frank Zappa to Black Sabbath (the real Black Sabbath, anyway), I am counting on it because I can see how awful society will become without real music.Alas, Cab Calloway, John Belushi, and John Candy are no longer with us to see that the legacy of this film is still as strong and defiant against stagnant radio drivel as it was in the early 1980s. Calloway in particular gives a performance that shows what a mistake society is making by throwing real music on the scrapheap. The performance of Minnie The Moocher convinced me in five seconds flat that I wanted to be a musician. Now that the DVD is out, grab it and watch it on a widescreen unit with the Dolby Digital 5.1 soundtrack turned up to full bore... you'll be a better person for it.

reviews.review_title: THE BEST MOVIE THAT I HAVE EVER SEEN!
reviews.content: The Blues Brothers is an absolute classic of a musical and strongly deserves to be in the Top 250 Somewhere! John Belushi puts in his greatest role ever as Jake Blues, the big (but short) brother of Elwood Blues who is sensationally played by Dan Aykroyd. After Jake (John) is released from Jail after a 3 year jail sentence, His Little (But Tall) brother Elwood (Dan) picks him up in a "POLICE CAR!" After being rejected by their female mentor from the orphanage they grew up in, they are inspired after a church service which their step-father (Cab Calloway) told them to go to. The Church service was conducted by James Brown, and the brothers set off on their MISSION FROM GOD to put the band back together, grab some bread and put it into the orphanage to redeem themselves. This would save the orphanage from being closed down, and getting the money was a very tough assignment. Their are hilarious moments, great duels with the cops that were chasing after them and wonderful music with a big list of guest stars, including Ray Charles, Aretha Franklin, The Blues Brothers Band and many, many more! This is the greatest musical ever made, my favorite movie! 10/10

reviews.review_title: Too ambitious of a project is detrimental to the end result
reviews.content: I saw this during it's initial theatrical release and have seen it many times since. This movie was far too of an ambitious project. When you have so many characters and musical numbers and musical legends and comic legends built around a thin main plot and weak subplots the entire picture collapses upon itself. This is still a funny and clever movie but it's just too cluttered. As it begin with some funny sight gags with Frank Oz taking inventory of Joh Beleushi's belongings and Beleushi throwing the cigarette lighter to Dan Akroyd's Bluesmobile out of the window it had some nicely paced comedy but as the film evolved into a musical with an overabundance of soul and blues legends it disintegrated into a movie that couldn't make up it's mind to be a comic adventure or a music video. The car chase scenes and mega-multiple car crashes were way too long and overboard and added nothing to either the comedy or music direction that this film was torn into going. In supporting roles, Henry Gibson, Carrie fisher, John Candy, and Frank Oz were all very good while Kathleen Freeman was excellent. Music legends James Brown, Ray Charles, Cab Calloway, Artetha Franklin, Chaka Khan, John Lee Hooker, Pinetop Perkins, Steve Lawrence and 60's fashion model Twiggy are all featured here as well as the Blues Brothers Band featuring former Memphis Stax records musicians. Cab Callowy and Aretha Franklin were very good in their roles but too many musicians spoiled the soup. Some delivered some exceptionally bad acting too. Director John Landis had success with Animal House and Kentucy Fried Movie before The Blues Brothers and would enjoy sporadic success as a director in the 80's and 90's with such films as An American Werewolf in London, Trading Places, Twilight Zone: The Movie and Coming to America. Longtime Landis associate film editor George Folsey Jr. really did a good job on what must have been a monumental task of editing the footage that went into this epic production to make some sense out the the mess that Landis conjured up to give us The Blues Brothers movie. This is not a bad movie as a whole but could have been a lot better. Any viewer will find some laughs and some great music here that they will appreciate once you sort through what is irrelevant. Because of it's large musical cast however, it does serve as an historical document. I would give this a 7.5 out of 10.

I'm not surprised this movie is not on IMDb's Top 250 and I can't really argue with people who think it's no great shakes. It's their loss. For me, it's one of the most fun movies ever made.I don't know what make movies great, but I think if I enjoy my 2 hours, it makes the cut. The Blues Brothers has a great 'repeat value', in the sense that it gets more fun to watch every single time. The soundtrack is great, the little cameos will keep you interested throughout and the shots of Chicago will make you want to be there.But above all, it is the whole attitude of the movie that makes it so special. Fans of the movie know what I'm talking about. And for those of you who haven't seen it, I'm not giving away anything. You either get this attitude or you don't. But do watch it, you might just be lucky enough to pick it up and become a fan. Elwood asking a random girl to meet him 'if her date don't work out' and her actually showing up is exactly the attitude I'm referring to.It's a longish movie and I've seen it a few hundred times. But still, on any given day, I am likely to fast forward to the bit when Jake and Elwood enter the arena for their final performance through the ladies' washroom and watch the movie down to a very exciting, exaggerated and thoroughly uplifting ending. I think IMDb's top 10 is roughly accurate, I wouldn't debate. But none of those, and I do adore each one, is a movie that make me want to 'be' the main character. This movie does. I'd give up whatever I have going to be Jake or Elwood, any given day.

Two musicians attempt to get their old band back together in a mission from God to raise money for their Catholic home.Released almost 30 years ago now this John Landis musical extravaganza will make you laugh, sing along and enjoy the comedy capers of some cool collected characters.Opening with a disguised Joe Belushi being released from prison the film builds a slow and already joyous notion through John Landis' comic styling. The high angled shot of Jake Blues standing behind the yellow line and leaning over is great and when we finally see his face that adds a deft touch to our outlook of the film. His expressionless yet sophisticated notion bouncing off his brother's equally non-emotional face sets the film up for more comic demonstration.As the two drive off Jake is highly unimpressed with the new "Blues mobile" which encourages his brother Elwood to drive it over the uplifting bridge which in any action film this would get the blood pumping but in this case it will get the mouths moving as the two land, completely unfazed and talk about Jake's redemption and thus the story begins and the music roles.The pair must gather $5000 in a week in order to save their growing up residence, a catholic home where "the penguin" and Curtis place expectancy on the pair and from there, enjoyable mayhem ensues as they attempt to reform their band.This is an enjoyable feel good motive for a film that encodes religious iconography that does reasonable justice to the faith even if the eventual conclusion of the money earning plan is dealt with too quickly. The intentions of doing the right thing for the right reason are what have won this film over.Which, in a way, is quite humorous. For a story and a situation that should be serious this is frequently hilarious. From the pair abusing and robbing off pub owners to wrecking a shopping mall this has the right elements to create a feel good atmosphere and will have you chuckling away. Carrie Fisher's mysterious unnamed action woman is truly a comic treat but the brilliance of unfazed Blues Brothers gives this a finely articulate touch.What make this film so unique and special are its wonderful cameos from musical legends. Cab Calloway, Aretha Franklin, James Brown and Ray Charles are the main players and singers all wonderfully used to justify the means of their situations. From Brown's preacher to Franklin's lonely wife worker their fitting characters add an extra touch of realism and with such a wonderful music score their inclusions are arguably the strongest implementation.This has a few faults in that realism is unlikely following assassination attempts and the law restrictions for the cops wouldn't happen and the ending is perhaps too problematic and an injustice after everything but this is a cracking film, a true musical feel good appreciation of life and music

I finally saw this movie.  People have been talking about this movie since as long as I can remember, calling it the funniest movie of all time.  Well, I had very high expectations for it, and I was let down.Number one, to call this movie a comedy isn't right.  It's a musical.  Okay, a musical.  The movie is filled with scenes where they break out with song.I love blues so I really enjoyed the music.  I wish B.B. King had made a cameo appence in this.In a way, I liked the movie.  I love the ending car chase.  This movie isn't call the highest car death movie for nothing.  I was not let down with the action, or the music.  I was disapointed in how funny it was.  It's just not that funny.  If you think singing is funny, you'll laugh your ass off.  But seeing how music isn't that funny, there is no comedy.  There is some slapstick comedy, but nothing groundbreaking.I do think it is by far the best SNL movie, though that's not really saying much  (I liked it better than Wayne's World).7 out of ten

It is truly a rare occasion that I can say I find no fault with a film. I can almost always think of something I would have done a little differently with each one I see. With The Blues Brothers, I am at a loss to do so.This film has been a part of my life as far back as I remember. I must have been no older than seven when I first saw it. It was always one of those movies my sister and I would secretly watch after our parents had gone to bed. I suppose it was all the profanity that hooked us back then. Now, I have a full appreciation for what this film really is.
The Blues Brothers is funny, exciting, ironic, spiritual, musically superior, and any other positive terminology I come up with all in one. From the first scenes of Jake being released from prison, to the final scene where the entire band is back in prison, this film never stops entertaining.
I'd say my favorite portion is the part towards the middle when the group attempts to play a gig at Bob's Country Bunker. The band tries playing their usual set to a bunch of rowdy rednecks, and they get about a thousand beer bottles flung at them for their trouble. After finally winning the crowd over, they then skip out on their $300 bar tab. This film has cameos a plenty, car chases, great music, numerous one-liners, and a truly unique feel to it. I have never even tried to watch the sequel since so many people told me it sucks.The Blues Brothers experience is one that will never be duplicated!I see no other choice but to give it 10 of 10 stars.So sayeth the Hound.

reviews.review_title: Great classic thats just plain FUN!
reviews.content: This all star cast really made a lasting movie. I love this movie. It rates right up there among my very favorite -having seen it over 300 times before I quit counting, I STILL notice a detail or two, from time to time. I've yet to meet anyone who didn't enjoy this -when they watched the DVD or older VHS theatrical release. The 'edited for TV' version is just so much wasted time and space -they really managed to steal all of the soul and heart out of the movie -and thats not easy! It has virtually no 'dead' parts -but its not one of those 'up tight' movies where you have to pay absolute attention to everything or you miss the point, either. Any who are old enough to have been a fan of the 'blues brothers' when they were on saturdaynight live, will truly enjoy this. If you just want some good laughs, plenty of great one-liners with perfect delivery, its still an excellent choice.

reviews.review_title: Essential to the understanding of American culture.
reviews.content: A film to be viewed if only for the preservation of performances by icons of American culture, including Ray Charles, Aretha Franklin and the inimitable Cab Calloway.Far and away the best of the NBC's Saturday Night alumni films, though that is to damn with faint praise. Only 'Caddyshack' is in the same level of merit.Fantasy and music in perfect proportion, though the unstinting use of filthy language makes this a production unsuitable for children or adults easily offended.The National Socialist White Peoples' Party could have been deleted without loss of any kind to the film. While Skokie Nazis may have been topical at the time of the filming, their inclusion is not amusing or entertaining in any way now.Background traverses wrong way when the Bluesmobile is revolving during first police chase scene, though this has been amply discussed.No shootings, stabbings, the only violence is comic. No nudity, no sexual situations but repellent language galore. No drug abuse but much tobacco consumption and some ethanol use.View the musical scenes if not the entire film.jHh

reviews.review_title: Two smart boys doing some not so smart things
reviews.content: A well written comedy, with really well written characters. Every main character is amazing- can't say the same for the other people in the film. Still worth a watch though.

A Hit from SNLI grew up with this movie. It was the first "R" movie I ever saw. I had always been a fan of blues and rock, a fan of musicals, comedies and SNL. SNL has many movies based on skits from them this movie has to be one of, if not the top one. It has great music from a excellent bunch of musicians. And great acting from a nice bunch of performers. John B. had always been into music, and on SNL has portrayed many singers to a great like. He is also one of the funniest guys out there. He has got to be one of the best motion picture comedians and physical comedians. He was a stunts man as well, he liked to do a lot of his own stunts, which by looking at him his hard to believe. Dan A. has a great talent for music, playing an excellent harmonica, raised with the blues and still talks on a blues radio show. Great comedian and actor. Then the movie brings in some real musical talent; James Brown (The king of Soul) Aretha Franklin (if James is the king then she is the queen) Cab Calloway (All around great musician- writer, singer) Ray Charles (one of the greatest song writers and piano players) Donald 'Duck' Dunn (probably one of the greatest living bass guitar players) John Lee Hooker (Great blues musician and guitarist) Performers; Carrie Fisher- plays the crazed ex, a big step from Star Wars. ;) Pee-Wee Herman as a waiter, not a big part but I noticed him. John Candy the Cop, helping the cops with a vendetta. Very smooth. There are others I know I left out, but these are the ones that stand out in my mind. This movie is full of comedy line after line scene after scene. The signature watch break, police pile ups, and cursing. The movie is a tri story- A mission from god to get money for the orphanage, avoiding Jakes ex-girlfriend, and getting the band back together and keeping it together. and of course the smaller stories- avoiding the Nazis, cops, and good ole boys. Its an un-imaginable cast, a great story line and non-stop comedy.A excellent movie for all those looking for a great laugh and that love great music. This movie is a legend in its own rights and a classic. Maybe even a bit cultish.

reviews.review_title: It's like a fun roller-coaster ride filled with people you like.
reviews.content: There are many things to like about The Blues Brothers.One of those is John Belushi,one of the funniest individuals who ever lived.His movie work never quite surpassed his work on SNL,but never ceased to be funny.Who would have thought at the time that we would lose him so soon?Secondly,the chemistry between Belushi and Dan Aykroyd was incredible,which was evident on SNL,so we knew what to expect going in and knew we would not be let down,particularly since they introduced these very characters to us on the show.Also,strategically placed music stars in various roles throughout the film add to it's appeal,They were all great,but my personal favorite was Ray Charles as the store owner,who although blind,always seemed to know when he was about to be ripped off.The film moves along slowly,picking up lightning speed in various places,which also adds to the appeal.The car chase scene in the shopping mall is one of my all time favorite movie scenes.It's a classic.It's comedy so good that not even it's sequel could measure up.Good stuff.

In my book, there are two comedies that try to reach the level of "epic". The first is Steven Spielberg's 1941, the second is John Landis' The Blues Brothers.  Guess which is superior?  Landis is not a smart director (anyone familiar with Kentucky Fried Movie and American Werewolf in London can attest to that), but here his focus is more on the relationship and interaction between characters rather than typecasting.  While I am not familiar with the original Saturday Night Live skits, I can say that this is hands-down the best movie made off of the TV show.  Night at the Roxbury? Get real!Landis' camera is deeper this time around.  Much of the time he is letting events build up instead of forcing the humor.  Thus, he creates the persona of The Blues Brothers without making something along the lines of Ghostbusters.  His message is simple: "They'll never get caught, they're on a mission from God."  How he conveys that almost parallels Dr. Strangelove in sheer ambition.  John Belushi surpasses his wave of mediocre roles (Animal House included) and creates the quintessential smart-ass.The comedy genre in itself is cursed because it is dependent on the viewer's intelligence and trying to appeal to a wide audience.  Landis has undoubtedly tried (Coming to America and Beverly Hills Cop III), but he is too mainstream to be taken seriously.  Thankfully, Dan Aykroyd (who is slightly more sophisticated in this sort of thing) is the one calling most of the shots with the script.  The dialog is punchy, catchy, and never gets useless.I hate musicals.  As far as I am concerned, songs in that line of work should stay on the radio and there alone.  Musicals are only trumped-up versions of the old Vaudeville performances (except nowadays we have MTV to turn us off).  While the Blues Brothers could have done without the music--it sure would've helped the running time--it does help keep it in the vein of "blues".  Music purists may debate that point now until they die, I don't care.The car chases in The Blues Brothers are two-sided.  On the surface, they represent the typical Hollywood pursuit.  The deeper subtext is that they parody the enormous waste Hollywood creates with such extravaganzas. Compare the final chase in all its humor and lack of seriousness with the overlong freeway chase in The Matrix Reloaded.  You can draw many similarities between the two in subtext as opposed to simple adrenaline rush.  Paging Michael Bay!  You are obsolete!Overall, a grandiose that overstays its welcome, but more than makes up for it.  This is Landis' best work, he will never improve.  Forget about everything else he made because here he finally combines what meager talents he has with a purpose.  4 out of 5 stars.

Except for the musical interludes, where the two lead characters don't perform, this movie is not that good. The story had potential but the movie was too over the top and Belushi and Ackroyd took themselves way too seriously. They can't sing and they can't dance. It was funny as a few SNL skits but that was it.Check it out if you're curious but don't feel guilty about skipping over scenes to get to the next musical break in the movie.

reviews.review_title: One of the greatest tributes to blues masters ever...
reviews.content: One of the greatest tributes to blues masters ever. James Brown. Aretha Franklin. Cab Calloway. Ray Charles, Steve Cropper, Tom Malone. They're all here, strung together in all their musical glory by a sort of "plot," but who cares. Throw in one of the greatest chase scenes ever, neo-Nazis, Carrie Fisher as the woman scorned, and cameos by a who's who of the 80s, and you have a classic movie. Not to be dismissed as just another SNL Belishi- Aykroyd movie, to their credit, they have created a movie that provides a veritable shrine to the Chicago blues tradition. Put this one in your classic DVD collection, pop it in the player, and hang on for the ride.

Spoiler warning. This is how a comedy should be made, based on the very great happenings and characters. A lots of funny situations in this movie and with a big budget, this movie easily makes it all very entertaining in one-two-three! The highlights are many; although the two biggest are the energy-bomb in the church with the black folks and the WEST SIDE STORY look when playing with Ray Charles in a music store. The movie plays on the so very right chords to make it all good, the Blues Brothers being a couple of cool guys who really get themselves into trouble, and the movie is also packed with weird characters like the wannabe-assassin woman, or the weird Nazis, and what about John Candy making pilot sunglasses even look small! THE BLUES BROTHERS is a terrific movie that keeps it up with the audience, and keeps delivering the goods in a tight and strict order. Belushi and Aykroyd are truly fabulous in their roles, wearing sunglasses and suits. And the movie always swings, there's always some kind of swingin' music rolling in the background, this making the whole mood very light and fine.It's a very good comedy, no doubt! James Brown being the Priest that makes the whole church explode into one big crazy circus and when Belushi sees the light, it all even gets more insane. Aretha Franklin playing in it too, and Ray Charles! There's dozens of known actors here, and that just adds the whole genuine part of it. The great climaxe that's truly a budget bomb with military, cops, MP's, guns, cars and everything just pushed together into a long car chase, all off course chasing the Blues Brothers. It's an absolutely highlight in the history of comedy making! STARS: 5/5

A truly great movie. I love Jake and Elwood Blues in this destined-to-be a classic. Between Dan Akroyd and the late John Belushi, the laughs pile up faster than the viewer can assimilate them. This film features some of the best car chase scenes ever recorded and this film is in the Guiness Book for wrecking a record number of cars during the filming. The music also truly shines! The boys are out to make enough money to pay the taxes on the orphanage where they grew up. The only way they know how is to put "the band" back together, but there are a few problems. First they have to convince the other players that they are for real. Then they need to find a gig. Then there's the time factor. This film is so much fun to watch that you just gotta rent it! That's an order!

reviews.review_title: this is the best movie ever
reviews.content: To criticise this movie is sacrilege, like criticising star wars or perhaps close encounters. The script is snappy, fresh and very appealing non-Americans like me [it took me 20 years to actually get the Wrigley fields joke though]. The opening scene is my favourite of all time, and I mean that! Frank oz ha ha ha ha the white line and finally Jake and Elwood hugging to taj mahals "she caught the Katy" I could rant and rave about this masterpiece for weeks - just watch this movie at least 20 times in your life -  a must 10/10 flawless

reviews.review_title: Should of had more music and less Hal Needham
reviews.content: I always hated Hal Needham movies with those 40 minute comic car chases but they were all the rage when this movie was made and about half ofnthis movie feels like a long boring car chase.The comedy isn't that great. There is a couple of funny scenes that stuck with me but that's not saying much when the film runs two and a half hours.What makes the movie is the music and the musical guests. Ironically, only one real blues artist appears in this entire thing, John Lee Hooker and he has a brief cameo performing Boom, Boom. EVeryone else is known for their soul or jazz music. Ray Charles, Aretha Franklin, James Brown, Cab Callaway. There could have been alot more instead of Hal Needham type crashes for an hour. I like the respectable cover of Taj Mahal's She Caught Katy.The movie was massively over budget so why couldnt they have used the money better by having more full time musicians? The list of blues musicians around then is extraordinary. Muddy Waters, Albert Collins, JB Hutto, Albert King, BB King, Etta James, Hound Dog Taylor, Junior Wells, Charles Musslewhite, James Cotton, Koko Taylor, Taj Mahal, a young Robert Cray, Willie Dixon, Mighty Joe Young (last two both had separete cameos in Thief at least). They could of had Professor Longhair! TIhe king of New Orleans jazz who was a card shark when his musical career dried up(revived again thanks mostly to the success of Dr John). I imagine it would have been a bigger thrill for all involved to meet all these guys and shoot a film with them but I guess someone decided it wouldn't be as commercial as a knockoff of Cannonball Run would be. What an irritating shame.What would have worked great was a movie like Frank Zappa's Baby Snakes with alot of performances and some what appears to be spontaneous scenes (but really skits) back stage in character. It would have fleshed out the concept born from the original sketch comedy premise than what they ended up doing and the musical guests would have felt more comfortable than they appear in the movie because they wouldn't be expected to so tightly adhere to a script. They could give real reactions. Aretha Franklin looked so uncomfortable in her scene that I felt embarrassed for her.I guess they misread the market or took the lazy way out or they were rushed into production in a desperate attempt to keep the momentum of Animal House and the hit selling Blues Brothers record alive but this could have been alot better.To their credit, they did rectify the mistake of short changing genuine blues greats by having plenty of guests in Blues Brothers 2000 but no one wants to remember that one. They should have been HERE.

I watch this movie three times and it's really good I'm a big fan of Dan aykroy he a really good actor all of his movies are good and John Landis is a really good director his movies are good too this movie has a lot of famous actors in it and this movie is the first snl skit they did its sad that John bluishe die at a young age he was a good actor and a funny guy too.

reviews.review_title: John Belushi would have been one of the greatest today!
reviews.content: I'm a big Belushi fan and this movie is one of those movies you can watch over and over again. The music is great and the hole concept is real perfection. A truly old cult classic and a great great movie should be there in the 250 top movies in my opinion. Aykroyd is also one of the greatest and if Belushi should be alive today i think those 2 people would have make a lot of classics movies.The Movie is about Jake and Elwood two brothers whos "On a mission from god" and the just gets into bigger and bigger troubles. The blues Brothers is a musical/comedy with some of the greatest musicians in the world. The late Ray Charles , Aretha Franklin late Cab Calloway and James Brown.. We shall not forget the band that also is very good.Its a shame that we never could see more of John Belushis fine work but while we still can lets go out and buy the new 25th Anniversary DVD and enjoy this masterpiece from this two comedy legends that Brought Blues To A New Age!

I have seen Blues Brothers so many times, i can recite it almost perfectly word for word. I have all the albums, and i even enjoyed the unfortunately not as good sequel.But why?Everything about the film says it shouldn't be up there as a classic, but in this case it is the exact reason it is. It does everything required to make it a true cult movie. Its totally over the top, the music is fantastic and the car chase is great fun. Not as good a car chase as the original "Gone in sixty seconds" done by the late great HB Halicki, but still a worthy holder of the "Most car wrecks in a movie" record.Its a shame John Belushi isn't with us still today, as his comedy timing and presence would have made some of our other classic movies very different (for the even better) "Ghostbusters" for example :)Anyways, this movie is and always will be a 10/10 from me.

reviews.review_title: If you have a sense of humor and love blues, you can't miss this one
reviews.content: I was like 14 when I saw this movie. I went with my best friend and schoolmate. Shortly after they started calling us the Blues Brothers at school... I don't recall a movie so hilarious with such great music. I've made all my family see the movie, however most hate it. My wife just bears with it. The car chases have no match.

Best musical comedy ever, everything is Here, good story, good acting, good music and entertainment !!! It's the movie to watch when you're sad, sick, better than every medicine on earth, I watch it two times per year since 25 years and even have a jake & elwood tattoo on my arm !!!
So buy it, watch it and just...... Enjoy !!!

If Rohit Shetty keeping his usual trademarks intact makes his masterpiece, it would almost be like The Blues Brothers. I went in without knowing anything other than the fact that it was a cult favourite, and I was wondering whether I was wasting my valuable three hours (the movie is two hours and thirteen minutes long) for something that I would be disappointed with (musical and comedy not being my favourite genres). But it is awesome! The brothers who seemed okay in the beginning became awesome-r by each passing moment. It is a high energy musical comedy with crazy stuffs happening now and then and believe me, when I say that you have not seen the like of this one. Never had so much fun while watching a movie for a long time until The Blues Brothers. P.S. And if you like your blues and soul, then the movie has Aretha Franklin, James Brown, Ray Charles and Cab Calloway to boast off.

Ok so I'm 43 now, decided to watch it, so glad I did, fantastic music, day after the amazing Aretha Franklin passed away, she was the best artist in the film. Really enjoyed the journey and the performances from the incredible cast.

reviews.review_title: Darien is only 20 miles from Chicago.
reviews.content: Being born, breed, and raised in the Chicago area means that Blues Brothers has a special place in my heart, quite naturally. It's a birth right of being able to watch the movie and take note of all the places you've been. This is the greatest Chicago movie of all time, mind you. Not to mention it's also one of the funniest movie ever. Say what you will about Animal House, Belushi is better in this. Personally I think Animal House is a little over rated. There's a secondary undescribable humor in Blues Brothers that only Chicagoans can see and nobody can explain. Small jokes through out the movie add to this inside joke. Dan Akroyd hasn't been the same since this movie came out. He has yet to find a roll to erase our memory of Elwood. Great performances are abound in tiny parts from other actors, Frank Oz, Charles Napier, Cab Calloway, Kathleen Freeman, John Candy (Orange whip? Orange whip? Three orange whips.), Henry Gibson and Ray Charles. Killer jammin soundtrack. Let's not forget this is a musical (the best and funniest ever). And then there's the car chases and car crashes. This is the only movie that can ever claim a car chase scene inside of a mall! Record number of cars were destroyed in filming this. And most of them were cop cars, BONUS! There's also the flying Nazi Car, it's a riot. And car 55 "We're in a truck" Plus ther'e at least two dozen memorable quotes, lines, and sets of dialogue. What more can be said of this movie? #12 on my all-time list.

reviews.review_title: Comedy Musical that is brilliant fm start to finish.
reviews.content: Dan Aykroyd and John Belushi star as two brothers Jake and Elwood Blue. After Belushi is released from prison the two brothers learn that the orphanage they grew up in is being closed down unless they can pay $5,000. Believing to be on a mission from god the Blues Brothers reform their old band to play a gig to raise money. Causing destruction wherever they go and picking up several enemies on the way. This is a comedy musical full of great musical moments and deadpan comedy, a true classic.

From the first time I saw this film, right through wearing out a video tape until getting the DVD I have enjoyed it thoroughly. The music is excellent and it has a good vibe throughout. Jake and Elwood might not be everyone's (or anyone's) idea as heroes but despite all of their faults they have an endearing quality about them. I like this film because to me it has humour, sensitivity, sadness, great music and a fine cast. The big getaway is something that appeals to kids especially (the rating of 15 is ridiculous and would probably be PG nowadays). Even though this film was panned upon its original release it has shown through subsequent years its enduring popularity. I, for one, am in no doubt that this is a genre defining film.

reviews.review_title: The best, the greatest, the best movie ever put on film!
reviews.content: Of all the movies that I have neither heard of or seen, I have never seen a movie that was so good, I had to watch it about 150 times. The Blues Brothers is the greatest movie a director has directed, a producer has produced, a writer has written or an actor has acted in. The Blues Brothers is a perfect example of how every good comedy should be made. John Belushi gives his greatest performance of his entire career as Jake Blues, he takes the character and makes it as good as it was written. Dan Aykroyd has never been better. In this movie, he shows that he's got game and that he can dominate a movie with such force in his character, it'll knock your socks off. The movie also features cameos from such famous musicians such as Aretha Franklin, Ray Charles, Cab Calloway and James Brown. The musicians are just as good as the rest of the cast was, some are great, some are very good and some are fall on your back hilarious! The Blues Brothers is the perfect movie for anyone who loves slapstick comedy, blues music, cars crashing and the combination of John Belushi and Dan Aykroyd. If you want a great comedy flick, go get this movie!

How can anyone not love this movie!? Extraordinary central performances from Belushi & Akroyd plus outstanding support from every other central character, with fabulous musical accompaniment from some the greatest talents of all time. Don't analyse the hysterical madness of this movie just embrace it for what it is - pure, unadulterated, fun.

reviews.review_title: A diamond between the comedy films...
reviews.content: "For me it will be a toast and for my partner here, 4 fried chickens and a Coke""The Blues Brothers": A really basic film for anyone who likes comedy films. It's like the Bible in the Catholic religion, like "Don Quijote" in a Literature class, like Darwin's "Natural Selection" in a Biology class. What I mean is, that "Blues Brothers" is the referent film in the most recent comedy films. This film marked the end of the old-style comedies that were already too used.If right now, you're thinking that I'm exaggerating, that means you've never seen the film. It mixes all the possible elements that can be used in the perfect comedies: 1.- Good jokes: not too silly, but simple enough to not thinking much about their meaning. 2.- Very good actors and remarkable invited stars: Two words: John Belushi. He's the film. I'm not underrating Dan Aykroyd, but without John, this film would have been a disaster. And of course let's include the very famous invited stars: Ray Charles, Cab Calloway, James Brown, Carri Fisher, etc. 3.- The songs: This element isn't necessary in all comedy films, but it helps. Unforgettable songs like "Everybody Needs Somebody", "Jailhouse Rock" or "The Rowhide Theme" make this film unique.So let's resume this article with 5 words: "This is THE comedy film".

reviews.review_title: the ultimate musical which is cool
reviews.content:
I bought the blues brothers yesterday on DVD and i haven't laughed my ass off since Elf. John Belushi and Dan Aykroyd play the blues brothers that are on a mission from God to raise money for a church. It has great musical appearances from Aretha Franklin, Ray Charles, James Brown, and a lot of people.
"Let me have some chicken wings"

reviews.review_title: Long live Jake and Elwood Blues ... A comedy classic
reviews.content: The Blues Brothers is, in a word, excessive. Director John Landis intended it that way. During a police chase he piles up not one or two cars but dozens.Dan Aykroyd and John Belushi were born for their roles as Jake and Elwood Blues and they are so ridiculous but seem so real, as if these two jokers could actually exist. To raise money for an orphanage, they set out to re-form their blues band for one big concert. In the process they run into Ray Charles as a pawn shop owner who does a song, James Brown as a preacher in an hysterical church scene, and Aretha Franklin as the owner of a greasy spoon who also does a song.Not to mention running into nutty Nazis, the entire Cook County sheriff's department, and tiny Carrie Fisher who fires everything from an assault rifle to a bazooka at hapless Belushi.Forget the French Connection for a car chase. The Blues Brothers has one of the greatest car chases ever filmed as the state troopers chase Jake and Elwood through a shopping mall.I can't forget to mention the famous scene in the country/western bar which is part of comedy screen legend.Look for Steven Spielberg, John Landis, John Candy, Twiggy, Frank Oz, Paul Reubens, John Lee Hooker, Joe Walsh, and Steve Lawrence in cameos.This film is a comedy classic with soul music and the unforgettable Jake and Elwood, two of the greatest comedic characters ever created.

reviews.review_title: A film about two brothers, a band, and a lot of car crashes.
reviews.content: Either you like The Blues Brothers, or you hate The Blues Brothers.  There is no inbetween.  I personally enjoy this film.  It's a redemption story. The Blues Brothers have to save their orphanage from foreclosure.  Along the way, they manage to incur the wrath of country singers, Illinois Nazis, the entire Illinois police force, the army, the national guard, Jake's jilted ex-wife, and a nun.  Mix in blues tunes with enough car crashes and car chases and you have yourself a film.  Now, I just have to figure out that trick Elwood does with the Bluesmobile when he escapes from the Illinois Nazis.

John Landis' fearless anarchistic movie of two brothers who try to raise $5000 to save an orphanage from demolition. The Brothers put their old band back together and go playing on the road with the police and some Nazi's chasing them. Lot's of brilliant dialogue and probably more (police) cars destroyed than in any other movie. Funny and full of action and great music.One can really see that making this movie must have been fun.

reviews.review_title: A funky mixture of music, action, and comedy
reviews.content: THE BLUES BROTHERS nearly rocked the house down in SATURDAY NIGHT LIVE during its late 70's era, and the black suit-donned brothers had hit the big time with their own feature film. Dan Akroyd and John Belushi are terrific as the Blues Brothers, kinfolks that trek along thecountry on "a mission from God," going on car wild car chases withthe cops along the way. But the brothers do what they do best, andthat's play the blues like there's no tomorrow.

Of all the top 100, 150, 200 lists I read on this board, no-one has included this classic piece of humour. Great cast, and music of the highest quality, this is one of the few musicals I can stand. Classics' like Singing in the Rain, and that one about children running about on hills, etc, all seem so out of place with reality, and I find them completely absurd. Sure they have good acting, music and so on, but, well, they're just horrible. Fine, The Blues Brothers isn't exactly in touch with reality, but it understands that it is not trying to be serious, or making some statement that only 1% of the viewers will grasp. It's about car chases; it's about the Blues, man. Almost every scene in this is memorable for whatever reason, and it should be appreciated much more than it seems to be on these boards. Wonderfully non-conformist. 9 out of 10.

When I first saw this movie I was about 5 or 6 and I have loved it all since.The movie is the ultimate musical comedy with some action.Very good music and very good acting by Dan Aykroyd and John Belushi as the blues brothers.This is John Landis best movie ever and it has stars Like: Ray Charles Aretha Franklin,John Lee Hocker,James Brown John Candy and even Steven Spielberg in small parts.One of the funniest movies ever made I give it 10/10

reviews.review_title: Possibly the greatest film of all time...
reviews.content: I grew up with this film and believe it to be the greatest ever made. It has great humour, excellent music, Nazis, a phycotic ex girlfriend armed with a rocket launcher, and without doubt the most spectacular and destructive car chase in film history. 10/10

In my recent weekly DVD hire, got out a few oldies including this "classic"."The Blues Brothers" is a movie about two brothers, Jake (Belushi) and Elwood (Akroyd), who besides having the unlikely surname of Blues, are part of a killer band. The movie picks up with Jake being released from prison after a 3yr stint and being reunited with Elwood. On the trip home they drop in to see their old Catholic nun who looked after them at the orphanage. She tells them of the pending closure of the home unless they can come up with 5 large. The brothers take this as if they have been given a mission by God to reform the band, do some gigs and come up with $5000. Over the next hour they seek out the old band members, some keener than other to reform. During the hunt we are treated to some great cameos from some other the legends of soul, including Aretha Franklin, John Lee Hooker and most notable Ray Charles with his brilliant performance of "Shake A Tailfeather". They then manage to book a big theatre for a huge show they hope will raise the money. Will it work? See it to find out.More a movie of some great scenes and cameos, but pretty patchy in spots. Belushi and Akroyd were pretty unaccomplished actors going into this and the movie heavily relies on gimmicks eg car chases than their acting prowess. Decent and holds up OK for a nearly 30yr movie.
This movie has aged splendidly. Classic music, classic characters and an awesome cast. Watch it with someone and turn them on to some great blues. And don't come back until you've redeemed yourself.

I remember when it came out i seen it in the theatre honestly it didnt excite me could be that Aykroyd s the worse actor ever but i think it was just to overdone, like how many famous people can we cram into a movie, more isnt better.

This movie can't cater to an international audience and/or the modern generation except for an instance or 2 (like the Nazi Captain's reminisceces of Hitler et al when his car's flying in the air). It's extremely difficult to relate to the gen're of music of those times and hence if that involves any humour then it's as good as redundant. And the exaggeration (helicoptors, tanks etc.) in the end can make anyone clutch his/her hair in agony. Because of this lack of explicit humour & implicit humour probably being too implicit, I found the movie pretty boring.

It doesn't matter where you go, you are unlikely to find a film as lighthearted, as shamelessly ludicrous and as ridiculously good fun as  "The Blues Brothers".  It does not have a plot, credible characters or believable situations.  And the wonderful thing is, it doesn't pretend it has.  That is where it's magic lies.Joliet Jake (the late John Belushi) is released from Chicago prison to meet his brother Elwood (Dan Ackroyd).  Returning to the neighbourhood where they grew up, the pair are horrified to learn the church-run orphanage that took them in as children is to be closed down.  Jake and Elwood then find themselves on a "mission from God" to reform their band "The Blues Brothers" to raise the money to save the orphanage.  Problem is, they keep making enemies everywhere they go.That is about as much story as there is in the entire film.  The rest of the movie's running time consists of slapstick comedy scenes, hilariously improbable car chases, and well-staged musical numbers featuring musical stars from the sixties and seventies (among them Ray Charles, Cab Calloway and Aretha Franklin).  Belushi and Ackroyd are two highly amusing leads.  With their suits, hats and shades and a barrage of well-placed one-liners, they make a lively pair of lovable rogues.  They're well supported by an array of  cameos including John Candy as the head cop on their case, Kathleen Freeman as "the penguin", Henry Gibson as a luckless neo-Nazi and Carrie Fisher, playing Jake's psychotic ex-girlfriend who ends up dropped in the mud.  There are many others.The musical numbers are guaranteed to have you up out of your chair dancing. Be it James Brown's divine "Landmark", "The Theme From Rawhide" or the concluding "Jailhouse Rock", there's something here for everyone.Relentless, unpretentious knockabout fun, there simply isn't another movie quite like this.

reviews.review_title: It is one of the most entertaining films for last 40 years
reviews.content:
Great comedy, great action.
Imho, it is one of the most entertaining films for last 40 years.Besides the members of The Blues Brothers band, the movie also features great musicians such as James Brown, Ray Charles, Cab Calloway, Aretha Franklin, John Lee Hooker.

reviews.review_title: The Mission From God Rocks On!
reviews.content: I watched The Blues Brothers: Collector's Edition DVD tonight.It has some new footage and has been digitally remastered.  It really is "A Collector's Edition."  I'm actually going to keep this one instead of returning it!Joliet Jake really is on "A Mission From God."  The way that he gets the band together and sets out for their first gig with no gig scheduled is just like the way Christ would say to the Apostles, "Follow me," with no worries about what to bring along for the trip.  Jesus even let a thief act as his Treasurer.Jesus cursed a fig tree for not being ready for Him.  Jake and Elwood encounter a gas station that has no gas for them, and ironically the gas station explodes behind them when they finally get on their way.As for Jailhouse Rock at the end, I think that has always been an inside joke that Elvis is really still alive!  The reason why all the prisoners are dancing in the aisles is that they've finally seen the light and are having the type of epiphany Jake had when he did front hand springs up the aisle in the church.I must have watched The Blues Brothers on VHS 30 times or more over the years, and I'd always thought I knew who Carrie Fisher's "Mystery Woman" was based on.  It wasn't until tonight that I realized that she was planning to kill Elwood the whole time, as well.The new DVD is a gem.  I think that if they used cutting edge computer technology to throw in some Matrix style special effects with all the dancing, police cars flying, The Penguin sliding back inside her office, and John Belushi doing front hand springs up the aisle of the church, it would break all existing Box Office records!And speaking of "records," throw in a little more music and suddenly everyone realizes that it always has been a musical!The use of the Peter Gunn theme has always been cool, and if I could request a song for the new theatrical release, I'd like to request that Henry Mancini theme from the original Pink Panther when David Niven and Robert Wagner are skiing.  I always thought that theme was a cool one, too.I'd like to see The Blues Brothers in one of those new totally digital theaters.  In that way, the timing could be controlled to allow for the audience laughter and applause.  The brightness could be adjusted so that everyone in the audience wears Blues Brothers 3-D sunglasses.They could even put in a young Paul Schaeffer with today's technology, as if he'd always been in the film all along!Could a a digitally remastered movie from 1980 win an Academy Award in 2002? It's easy when you're "on a mission from God!"

reviews.review_title: There Is A Smokie In My Truck
reviews.content: I was sitting in a cafe at a mom and pop truck stop. The cook was a former gear jammer.He was telling me that he was tooling down I-57 out of Chicago. He felt his rig rock violently. He looked out his rear view mirror and saw a cop car hangin out of his 53' trailer. But he said he promised his wife to take her to an Evie concert. And if mama isn't happy,no one is happy. So,he just grabbed another gear and kept on going.Carrie Fisher,Aretha Franklin, Kathleen Freeman,Twiggy, the Soul Food Cafe dancers,the chick dancers at the Tripple Rock, and the chick dancers outside of Rays are hot!!!---One Truck Drivers Opinion---erldwgstruckermovies.com

reviews.review_title: Wildly entertaining and never misses a beat.
reviews.content: Wild and extremely interesting musical comedy based on the SNL skit where two brothers: Jake (John Belushi) and Elwood (Dan Aykroyd) go out on the streets of Chicago to reunite their band in order to raise money to keep the orphanage (where the two men grew up) in business within two weeks.Throughout their quest, the brothers have to deal with what seems like an endless slew of obstacles (cops, Nazis, etc.) that stand in their way. The script, written by Aykroyd and director John Landis ("Animal House") never fails in delivering one hilarious moment right after another whether it's a sight gag or a one-liner. Even the songs (if you enjoy music especially jazz, blues, or both), some of which are performed by Elwood and Jake and/or legends such as James Brown, Cab Calloway, John Lee Hooker, and Aretha Fanklin are just as entertaining as the film itself.Belushi and Aykroyd are both wonderful yet unflappable in the lead roles and I still can't make up my mind in which who was better here."The Blues Brothers" is wildly entertaining and never misses a beat.

I saw this movie in high school, and thought it was the funniest film I had seen. I would watch it over and over on my own and with mates, and just be in absolute fits of laughter. And now, many years out of high school, I can still put this movie on and find myself rolling in laughter still. It is just one of those movies that never ceases to be funny. Its just awesome.But no matter how funny this movie is, it is still the music that does it. Putting legends like Aretha Franklin, Ray Charles, James Brown, Cab Calloway, and John Lee Hooker in one movie is just amazing. Add to that the musicians in the Blues Brothers Band, and the under-rated voice of Belushi, and its just a complete new level for this movie.Pretty much, if you have any liking of movies that make you laugh and/or amazing music, this is a movie you must see. 10/10

I've looked up this movie in the 'Best Comedy Movies List' .I got bored to death during the first 30 min and had to turn it off after the scene where our 'heroes' drive through a Toys'R US store full of children.I've seen excellent comedy movies from 80s and this is not one of them.

This movie is not only hysterical, it is also a great tribute to blues music.  This is one of the greatest comedies and music movied of our time. They were apparently on a "mission to God" to make this movie great and they suceeded.

As the tagline says, "They'll never get caught!  They're on a mission from God!"  Dan Ackroyd and the late John Belushi take their Saturday Night Live characters The Blues Brothers to the big screen!  Their mission is to get some money to reopen the orphanage in which they were raised that's being threatened to shut down.  So, Elwood gets Jake out of prison and their adventure begins!  They run into everything from rednecks, a homicidal old flame of Jake's, famous musicians and singers, and the authorities!  The Blues Brothers has something for everyone to enjoy.  Cool music, car chase scenes, location shots of Chicago home of the blues, and one hilarious mishap leading to another!  The funniest parts in the movie were the whole church scene where everyone was doing flips, and the whole chase scene that leads to the end of their 'mission'.    This is quite possibly the best movie about Saturday Night Live characters ever made!  All the others such as Wayne's World and A Night at the Roxbury were all mediocre compared to The Blues Brothers!  My favorite is Elwood because he's the smart and scheming one.  The Blues Brothers is a movie that nobody should pass by!  So go ahead and rent it already!  It's an awesome movie you can watch with friends and family alike.

reviews.review_title: The single best comedy film ever
reviews.content: This has to be the film that all comedy films must be measured by. I personally have to watch it every 2 years or so. The cast is like a who's who. No film has ever integrated great music so well into a film. Spielberg even plays a bit part in it. If you don't get and like this movie then I pray for your soul, wherever you lost it!

By definition, a classic comedy works across eras, with films like Animal House and Fast Times at Ridgemont High generating laughs to this day. I'm not sure if this movie was ever funny, and today it's unwatchable.Thanks to SNL and Aykroyd and Belushi's popularity, along with famous cast members from all sorts of professions, when released this flick drew huge audiences. I don't know why I watched it again last night. I wish I hadn't.The acting is terrible, it vacillates poorly between being a comedy and a musical, there's no compelling plot and it runs too long. I get the impression that Belushi had to just show up to draw an audience, and it shows.Thinking of watching this? Find something, ANYTHING, else to do.

Although this movie is not very funny in terms of goofy hilarity or wicked puns or punchlines, it makes up for it with excellent music. The Blues Brothers, originally just a comedy act on the original "Saturday Night Live", had evolved into a genuine musical act that focused on performing soul standards and rhythm and blues. This movie showcases not only The Blues Brothers' talents, but those of a veritable "who's who" of soul, R&B, and jazz music. Cab Calloway, Aretha Franklin, John Lee Hooker, Ray Charles, and James Brown make the most of their cameo appearances, and entertain us with some of their classic hits. This is one of the best musical movies I've seen, because it features such a wonderful variety of American pop music. The background music is also excellent, and includes standards from Sam and Dave, Fats Domino, and Wilson Pickett.The music greatly helps in evoking the setting of the film, which is Chicago. Visual effects and sets are also a great help. The movie presents the Windy City in all of its gritty glory, from the grimy streets below the massive el-train trestles to the opening shot showing the billowing smoke from factories and flames shooting out of the chimneys of oil refineries. We also are shown images of plump Vienna sausage grilling on the stove in a soul food restaurant and the hustle and bustle of the city center. Clearly, the cinematographers did an excellent job in presenting their vision of a city that is one of the centers of R&B music.As for the massive car chases, they are indeed eye-popping and entertaining. The movie snowballs into hyperbole in the chase scenes that it almost seems credible. The special effects and vast array of extras to serve as national guard soldiers and policemen ensure that this movie certainly earns a reputation as a comedy epic, akin to "It's a Mad, Mad, Mad, Mad World." As for the acting, John Belushi and Dan Aykroyd hold their own as Jake and Elwood Blues, respectively. They're not laugh-out-loud funny most of the time, but they do their best to at least be consistently amusing and entertaining as the they're trying to reform their band, or are avoiding capture from an assortment of enemies. To their credit, they hold this movie solidly.John Landis did an excellent job at creating a movie that is both epic comedy and soul music musical. While the film ended up in the red when it premiered, time has been kind to this classic, and it will no doubt introduce a future generation to classic soul music.

The movie holds up quite well; despite the excess, it looks almost modest and demure by subsequent standards.  And it's not as if that excess isn't funny in this context - the juxtaposition of the rather abstract Blues brothers, sometimes conniving and self-serving (albeit justified by their supposed mission from God) but more often hermetically sealed in their own weird outlook and set of rules, largely oblivious to the vast property destruction and chaos following in their wake, is fundamentally a pretty good joke; and Landis'	 ceaseless commitment to pushing it further and further carries it right until the end (although he seems to undercut the very last joke through bad editing). The quirkily specific evocation of Chicago is an effective counterpoint; as is the very sincere and guileless enthusiasm for the music: the movie's ambition to act as a showcase for a classic line-up of soul/r&b performers  is a great asset in time capsule terms. It's more interesting (or at least innocuous) than funny, with relatively few laughs. But there's a lot of genuine engaging oddity - the extremely long walk through the prison yard in the opening sequence; the one-off stylistic parodies in such scenes as the confrontation with Freeman; the cover of Rawhide; the strange tenderness as they go to sleep in the dingy apartment near the train tracks.

This movie is among my favorites. Although it may seem excessively goofy at some points (Example: The Nazis flying in the air), it still does not fail to reach comedy gold. The acting is outstanding, the cinematography is on point, and the most important thing, the soundtrack, is filled with great songs. The problem with this movie is that some parts are confusing, like the Minnie The Moocher scene. How did they change into the performance so quickly, and how did they change back? Another thing is the fact that they never met the goal established in the beginning. They never payed the taxes, so they failed at helping the orphanage. Over all, I think the movie is a very fine piece of cinema. 8/10
Just the best movie of its time and it still holds up against all the self righteous crap that's churned out of the movie screens these day.s. Absolute gem

reviews.review_title: The Greatest car chase movie of all times.
reviews.content: This is the undisputed dominating movie when it comes to car chases.  No other movie has ever been able to come anywhere close to equalling that of The Blues Brothers.

reviews.review_title: If only more movies could be like this
reviews.content: I love The Blues Brothers. It's a great, fun, funny movie and the only musical that I like. Jake and Elwood Blues are a pair of performers, albeit fictional, that know what it takes to put on a good show. The music in the film is one of the best things about the movie, coming as it does from quite a few real musicians. The Blues Brothers hold the record for the number of cars destroyed in a chase scene, and the final chase scene is a sight to behold. The star-studded cast is excellent and the movie is just a showpiece for all of these stars. This is by far the best film ever made from a Saturday Night Live sketch, and one of the best movies to feature Dan Ackroyd. Bottom Line: Forget the horrible Blues Brothers 2000, this movie is the real McCoy. It occupies a valued space in my collection.

reviews.review_title: My Favorite Movie of All Time!
reviews.content: Watched in 1980 and many, many times in the 42 years since. Had everything - comedy, action, music, and unbelievable car chases. And the story line was fantastic. Never gets old. Leads were wonderful - and hysterically funny! From John Belushi and Dan Akroyd (the Blues Brothers) to Kathleen Freeman (Catholic Nun) and father figure Cab Calloway, plus music stars like James Brown, Murphy Dunne, guitarist Steve Cropper, guitarist Donald 'Duck' Dunn, drummer Willy Hall, and sax player Tom Malone. And even Ray Charles! The musicians were world class - all of them.I challenge you to find a 1980 movie with such a cast, not even counting the "bad guys"/police.Favorite scenes abound, and the cast was simply top notch. And the musicians were world class - all of them.My favorite movie of all time - and I am old!

reviews.review_title: This film is a tribute to America
reviews.content: This film was the Friday late night film in Stuttgart for seemingly years, which means that many people were seeing it time and time again. I didn't catch up with it, myself, for 20 years. The film exudes joy, has something for everybody. It's a road movie through American culture. It's got that magical pairing of John Belushi and Dan Ackroyd. Dan's got to be the dryest and coolest anti-hero ever!! Above all of course it's got the music, which I didn't even know I like before I saw this film. A timeless cult-classic- sorry I wish I could be more eloquent!!!

This the movie I've seen the most times, seventeen, and I think it's about time I watched it again! I can only say that there's some genius in it. I'm not sure what it is, but you'll feel it as soon as you let yourself go to the great music and the surrealism of the story.10/10

reviews.review_title: Why are you bothering to read the heading?
reviews.content: I first saw this film on TV three years ago, on the recommendation of my dad, and as it was on late in the morning (with swear words still deleted I might add), I taped it and then intended to tape over it afterwards. I've never done that. It has since become my all time favourite film, but it didn't start out that way. After seeing it for the first time, my reaction was: "Well, it's not bad... I can see why it's a cult movie... all that singing would be good in a cinema, but it's not great." Somehow I decided to watch it once more before taping over it, and this time I really started to like it. Over the end credits I actually got up and started dancing (I have no life, I know), and I knew there was something happening cause I'd never done that before. I think that it actually does get better on a second viewing, just because the beginning is so slow going (all that silence), you expect the rest of the movie to be like that, which of course it's not. **What I'm saying is.. watch this movie twice!!** I love this movie, mainly because I feel indebted to it for helping to get me listening to blues and also old rock and roll. Before I saw this I just put up with whatever teeniebopper crap was on the radio, but then I bought the soundtrack, then heaps of other Blues Bros stuff, then I dug out my families old record colection (that hadn't been played for 10 years) and now I hardly listen to the new stuff. For this I am grateful. It also got me watching cult movies, before I saw this I never saw myself watching things like Plan 9 From outer Space. In short, this one movie changed my life, my tastes in music, movies and fashion. It taught me what makes a good comedy, it inspired me to track down old SNL tapes, and I was introduced to John Belushi, and the talent of Dan Aykroyd (who I'd never liked much till I saw this). By the way, why does everyone praise this as Belushi's film and brainchild, when it was Aykroyd who suggested the band, who introduced Belushi to the blues, who wrote the screenplay? Oh well. Whoever you are, go and see this film. Now. If you've already seen it, then see it again. Good. Now wait three days and watch it again. Buy the soundtrack. Or better yet, buy the Blues Brothers complete (all three albums rolled into one). Now go to a late night screening of it. Very good. See, that wasn't so hard was it? And once you've seen the best film ever made (this one, dummy), go and read the best book ever written: Catch 22. You'll never be the same again, I promise.

reviews.review_title: Not as great as you would be led to believe.
reviews.content: The blues brothers picks up with Jake Blues being released from prison and being picked up by his brother Elwood Blues. They visit the old orphanage where they were raised and learn that $5,000 is needed or the government will shut it down. They decide that the best way to get the cash is by legal means, that is by gigging with their band. But first they must reassemble the band. And so begins John Landis' The Blues Brothers. The primary problem that I had with the film was that it overdid itself as a musical. There was too much music. Did we really need to listen to the band play entire selections? Other than that, it's pretty great. The late great John Belushi is priceless as usual. I liked him better in Animal House.7/10 Cons : Too much music and the train going by the window every few seconds was annoying.Pros : Too many to list. They definitely outweigh the cons by a mile.

The Blues Brothers is, quite simply, one of the best films of the 1980's. Never before has the city of Chicago been so beautifully captured on film. Every frame of the film has been carefully planned and executed.  The attention to detail is amazing.  The photography, the choreography, the music, all breathtaking.  Stay away from pan-and-scan, this one belongs on a wide screen.  I hope that as time goes on more and more people begin to look at this as more than just a Saturday Night Live movie.  This is an urban epic.  John Landis' finest moment.

reviews.review_title: Four steps in making a classic musical comedy
reviews.content: I saw this film for the first time in 1994 in a small town where I happened to study for a year, in the local movie theater for a ridiculously low sum of money. A school class had organized a screening of the film to help finance a class trip or something. The print was in rather bad shape, and the audience a bit too loud, but I had a great time. This film became my favorite along with "Hatari!" and "Father of the Bride" (the Steve Martin remake). Everything in this film is just right:The attitude: Jake and Elwood manage to keep their coolness no matter what obstacles come their way. With cops in hot pursuit, they totally demolish a shopping center, while calmly discussing everything that's sold there (check out the worker who accidentally bumps into the camera while trying to run to safety). A mysterious woman (Carrie Fisher!) destroys a seedy hotel where Elwood lives, but that doesn't seem to bother the brothers, who climb out of the pile of debris, wipe the dirt off their suits and carry on walking.The music: James Brown's enthusiastic Soul Preacher engaging a whole churchgoing audience (including Belushi and Aykroyd) into a wild gospel number where everyone starts singing and swinging on the floor (some even jumping high up close to the roof, defying the laws of gravity). Aretha Franklin shows she has a way with words and tells Matt Murphy to "Think about what you're trying to do to me". Ray Charles displays his talents by "Shaking the Tailfeather" in a music shop, with the whole street joining in the fun. The funniest scene in the country bar, where the audience, irritated by "Gimme Some Lovin'", has to be calmed down by renditions of "Rawhide" and the sure-fire tearjerker "Stand by Your Man". Not to forget Cab Calloway's "Minnie the Moocher" and the titular band's takes on "Everybody Needs Somebody" and "Sweet Home Chicago".The humor: Just see the Quotes section for this one, there are plenty of memorable lines in this movie.The faces: Landis puts in his usual assortment of film directors and other familiar faces in cameo roles: Frank Oz as a prison officer at the beginning, Steven Spielberg young and unrecognizable to those who know only his bearded mug shots of today, and Landis himself as a policeman joining his colleagues in the shopping center chase scene. Paul "Pee-Wee Herman" Reubens as the waiter who takes the brothers' dinner orders in the restaurant, and Twiggy as a girl whom Elwood asks for a date. And don't blink or you'll miss long-haired and mustachioed rock singer and brief The Eagles member Joe Walsh during the closing "Jailhouse Rock" number.Stock up on dry white bread and whole fried chickens, invite your friends to join in, and have a good time together with a movie filled with SOUL!
Why wasn't that 1974 Dodge Monaco not considered for an Oscar? His performance had me in tears.

I really can't tell what was missing from this film, why I didn't like it much. I usually like silly and over the top comedies and i like musical movies. So this movie would have been predestined for me. The musical numbers were good, but not as good as in other musical movies. Unfortunately the movie was hardly funny for me, i didn't care much about the story and the characters. Maybe my expectations were just too high because of the cult status of the movie.
